title: What do you think of Full Stack Web Application Development?
body:
Hi Cory,





I am just going through your HTML5 Web Component Fundamentals course on Pluralsight... I am a complete beginner with some mandatory holidays, caused by the virus, so I decided to create a web application. I have written macros in excel before, and a few macros for a 3D design software both using VB, but that is about all my coding knowledge. I have watched about 45 hours of Pluralsight courses in 4 days, and I struggle to find the relevant things, as most beginner videos explain the basics too basic, but don't go into details on the genuinely new info. (I don't even need coding to understand what an if - else statement is - my mom shouted it at me enough as a child -, but what on earth is git? Sure I downloaded and installed it to follow the demos, now what, will it scan my entire computer and sell all my personal data???)  Yes I have very serious trust issues.





Your course was the first one that I actually started to find interesting, and the one that made most sense.





As I am drowning in resources - there are 95+hrs of Pluralsight courses on HTML CSS and JS (basics), purely on how to write these from scratch - a common element in these courses is: "Here is how you do it from scratch on your own, but don't do that, here is 5 alternatives for - libraries, frameworks etc. but you also have to learn these on top of what you just learned, they will introduce issues with dependencies, and you will struggle to switch between these. Good luck!!"





So 5th day into learning web application development I think I would like to go down the Full Stack route, assuming I understood that term right (Developing both Front and Rear end) and re-invent every wheel that rolls my way. <joke>Luckily as a Mechanical Design Engineer working in Motorsports, that's also what I do when I am not on holiday</joke>





After the essay, here are the questions:


- Whats your preferred method of deploying your web applications? 


- Why? 


- How are you certain that they are safe, both from hackers and from the third party you are/may be deploying it through? (I have trust issues with completely free resources that just say "promise we won't look" in a fancy formatted document)





The app I am developing (a demo for - as a first project) exists already and was created in the early 2000s and is unsupported now. It handles personal data, and while I will not input any real GDPR sensitive data into my demo app, I would like to begin development with the condition that it must be THAT secure. 





- What are 'Must have'-s even if I try to go about it the 'From Scratch' way?


- Do you have any more courses that go into detail on any of the topics I mentioned in my essay? (Security, frameworks and libraries, 'New Starter - kit' of 'Must Have'-s?


- If you personally don't, can you recommend certain courses to watch, read, work through?





Thank you!


Sorry for the long post! 


(Here is a Potato)

title: AO3-5915 Write TOS acceptance to cookie when localStorage not available
body:
## Issue





https://otwarchive.atlassian.net/browse/AO3-5915





## Purpose





Some browsers that support localStorage do weird things like stop you from putting anything in it in private mode. This means visitors using those browsers can't get past the GDPR TOS prompt.





So what we're doing here is testing setting something in localStorage and then, if that doesn't work, repurposing it to create (or update or remove) a cookie.





## Testing Instructions





Refer to Jira.





## References





Refer to code comments.

title: How to load secrets in to environment variable on Linux POD
body:
I am using the below things. However, I need to be able to load these secrets onto env variable. It is not working at all. Could you please help us how to achieve that?





apiVersion: v1


kind: Pod


metadata:


  labels:


    app: nginx-flex-kv    


  name: nginx-flex-kv


  namespace: ns-gdprhub-kc


spec:


  containers:


  - name: nginx-flex-kv


    image: nginx


    imagePullPolicy: Always


    command: ["sh", "-c"]


    args: ["export KEYCLOAK_USER=$(cat /kvmnt-kc/gdpr-key-cloak-admin-user)",


      "export KEYCLOAK_PASSWORD=$(cat /kvmnt-kc/gdpr-key-cloak-admin-user-pwd)"]        


    volumeMounts:


    - name: secrets-store-inline-gdprhub-kc


      mountPath: /kvmnt-kc


      readOnly: true


  volumes:


  - name: secrets-store-inline-gdprhub-kc

      readOnly: true


      volumeAttributes:


        secretProviderClass: "azure-scp-gdprhub-kc"

title: Unable to log in with basic-auth due to GDPR mode
body:
I'm unable to log in with basic-auth due to GDPR strict mode which is now enforced.





### Description


When trying to authenticate with JIRA during first request, I get an error saying I can't use username.





### Reproduction


```python


jac = jira.JIRA(


    server="https://<myorg>.atlassian.net/",


    basic_auth=(account_id, api_token),


    options={"rest_api_version": 3},


)


users = jac.search_users("example-user")


```





I've tried passing in username, display-name and email instead of `account_id`, and password instead of `api_token`, and still I get an error





### Expected behaviour


Successful authentication.





### Stack Trace


```


Traceback (most recent call last):


  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/client.py", line 2840, in search_users


    return self._fetch_pages(User, None, "user/search", startAt, maxResults, params)


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/client.py", line 640, in _fetch_pages


    resource = self._get_json(request_path, params=page_params, base=base)


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/client.py", line 3129, in _get_json


    r = self._session.get(url, params=params)


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/resilientsession.py", line 173, in get


    return self.__verb("GET", url, **kwargs)


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/resilientsession.py", line 169, in __verb


    raise_on_error(response, verb=verb, **kwargs)


  File "~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/jira/resilientsession.py", line 55, in raise_on_error


    r.status_code, error, r.url, request=request, response=r, **kwargs


jira.exceptions.JIRAError: JiraError HTTP 400 url: https://<myorg>.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/user/search?username=<api_token>&includeActive=True&includeInactive=False&maxResults=50


    text: The query parameter 'username' is not supported in GDPR strict mode.


    


    response headers = {'Server': 'AtlassianProxy/1.15.8.1', 'Cache-Control': 'no-cache, no-store, no-transform', 'Content-Type': 'application/json;charset=UTF-8', 'Strict-Transport-Security': 'max-age=315360000; includeSubDomains; preload', 'Date': 'Wed, 06 May 2020 03:49:32 GMT', 'ATL-TraceId': '82464007f0031d21', 'X-AREQUESTID': 'e4be7405-6a4e-4046-bce4-276a1ec43888', 'X-XSS-Protection': '1; mode=block', 'Transfer-Encoding': 'chunked', 'Timing-Allow-Origin': '*', 'X-Content-Type-Options': 'nosniff', 'Micros-Issuer': 'micros/edge-authenticator', 'Connection': 'close', 'Expect-CT': 'report-uri="https://web-security-reports.services.atlassian.com/expect-ct-report/global-proxy", enforce, max-age=86400'}
```

title: Cannot delete account
body:
**Versions (please complete the following information)**


- happens in all vis2k assets





**Describe the bug**


After creating an account, is it not possible to delete that account afterwards anymore.





This is very cumbersome for the admin to manage all deletion requests manually, especially if tons of accounts are getting generated when logging in with a typo (see previous bug report).





Also  important is the fact, that a missing delete option is violating the GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) of the EU that exists since 25th May 2018.

RIGHTS.PRINCIPLES: right to erasure, right to access

title: New segments for 'Ecommerce Order Revenue' and 'Revenue left in cart'
body:
It would be valuable to offer 2 new segments:





* Order Revenue (Ecommerce)


* Revenue left in cart  (Ecommerce)





It is already possible to segment on Order ID, Product name/sku/category. But revenue segmentation is not yet available.





It would be useful in many contexts for example create a segment for:


* Large orders


* ecommerce orders within a certain price range (using AND combination)


* (for example orders for "free trials" with a revenue of zero)


*  having the new segment means it'll now be possible to delete "Buggy visits with large abandoned carts" from skewing the data using our [GDPR tool delete visits data](https://matomo.org/faq/how-to/how-do-i-delete-rows-of-a-report-and-specific-visits-to-clean-up-some-of-the-reporting-data/) (Very large abandoned cart)

title: Self-Review Questionnaire: Security and Privacy
body:
Feedback has been to review this project through the lens provided by the Self-Review Questionnaire: Security and Privacy https://www.w3.org/TR/security-privacy-questionnaire/ established by the W3C. While we are not a W3C spec, it is a useful tool in evaluating our security and privacy posture. To this end I have attempted to answer the following questions for the CMCD project:





1. What information might this feature expose to Web sites or other parties, and for what purposes is that exposure necessary?


    1. This spec relays information from a media player to the CDN from which it is requesting media objects. The information concerns attributes of the object being requested (such as bitrate, duration, object type), the state of the player (buffer level, rebuffering status, startup mode) and the session (sessionID and contentID). The exposure is necessary because it allows the CDN to a) optimize delivery of the object b) apply intelligent timeouts and retry thresholds c) Analyze disparate requests as being a playback session and d) trigger immediate network health alerts for poor performance. 


2. Is this specification exposing the minimum amount of information necessary to power the feature?


    1. Yes, we believe so. Over 35 data points were originally proposed, of which we have accepted 16. We have evaluated each on the litmus test of "is it necessary" and "what is the benefit"? For each key/value pair accepted, we have a clear value proposition. 


3. How does this specification deal with personal information or personally-identifiable information or information derived thereof?


    1. All PII is explicitly prohibited. The spec indicates that "Personally Identifiable Information, such as IP address, cookie information and location data is intentionally not carried by the specification. "


4. How does this specification deal with sensitive information?


    1. None of the defined keys carry sensitive information, such as  financial data, health information, location, or credentials. 


5. Does this specification introduce new state for an origin that persists across browsing sessions?


    1. The "sessionID" key is the only data point that persists across requests. This ID is required to be a GUI and the UUID standard is suggested. It ties together the audio, video and manifest requests when a particular asset is played. It is never used twice, even if the same user plays another assets, or the same asset is repeatedly viewed by the end user. It cannot be used to identify the user, or the content and it does not persist across browsing sessions. 


6. What information from the underlying platform, e.g. configuration data, is exposed by this specification to an origin?


    1. Of the reserved keys, the ones closest to configuration data would be requested maximum throughput and buffer length. These can conceivably be set differently players at levels that could be averaged over time and then used as part of a fingerprinting surface. To mitigate this, the spec requires these values to be rounded to the nearest 100mbps. This bucketing lowers the entropy associated with these parameters and thus reduces the fingerprinting surface. An explicit key called 'DeviceID' was proposed but then removed from the spec due to fingerprinting concerns.  


7. Does this specification allow an origin access to sensors on a user’s device


    1. No it does not. 


8. What data does this specification expose to an origin? Please also document what data is identical to data exposed by other features, in the same or different contexts.


    1. The spec exposes the following information to an origin. In manby cases, the origin already has access to this information if it were to parse the object being delivered


        1. Encoded bitrate - the bitrate of the media object being requested . Origin can discover by parsing. 


        1. Buffer length - the buffer length of the media player


        1. Buffer starvation -  a Boolean flag indicating if a rebuffer event has taken place since the last object was requested. 


        1. Content ID - A unique string identifying the current content. This does not increase information leakage, as the object URL is visible to the receiver and itself a reference to the content. This ID simply ties together the thousands of separate objects which comprise a media asset. 


        1. Object duration - the media time duration of the object. Origin can discover by parsing. 


        1. Deadline - the minimum time for the CDN to deliver the object before the player rebuffers. 


        1. Measured throughput - the throughput between client and server as measured by the client


        1. Next object request - the next object the client intends to request. This is used to request a prefetch by the CDN edge. Must be a relative path to the current request. 


        1. Next range request - a range request associated with the next object request. 


        1. Object type	 - whether the current file represents an audio, video, init, caption, or manifest file. 


        1. Playback rate - current playback speed of the player


        1. Requested maximum throughput -  a means for a player to voluntarily ask for delivery to be throttled. 


        1. Streaming format - type of media presentation, such as HLS or DASH. 


        1. Session ID - a randomly generated GUID, such as UUID, used to tie together object requests across a single piece of media. 


        1. Stream type - live or VOD


        1. Startup	 - boolean true if the player is in start/seeking/recovery mode.


        1. CMCD version - version to accommodate future updates. Not sent if version == 1. 


9. Does this specification enable new script execution/loading mechanisms?


    1. No. 


10. Does this specification allow an origin to access other devices?


    1. No. 


11. Does this specification allow an origin some measure of control over a user agent’s native UI?


    1. No, this is client to server communication, not server to client. 


12. What temporary identifiers might this this specification create or expose to the web?


    1. The SessionID can be considered a temporary identifier. It is randomly generated, never repeats for the same user and is never reused for other sessions. 


13. How does this specification distinguish between behavior in first-party and third-party contexts?


    1. The first party receiver of the data is the CDN serving the media objects. The CDN will log this information in its delivery log files. Log files are considered proprietary data of the customer whose content is being delivered. These log files are subject to privacy constraints, such as GDPR. 


14. How does this specification work in the context of a user agent’s Private Browsing or "incognito" mode?


    1. A media player may optionally send the CMCD data. The spec does not restrain whether the data should be sent when a browser-based player is in Private Browsing mode. 


15. Does this specification have a "Security Considerations" and "Privacy Considerations" section?


    1. Yes, Section 5 deals with security and privacy concerns. 


16. Does this specification allow downgrading default security characteristics?


   1. This allows data to be attached to a HTTP request. If this request is made over http, then it is subject to man-in-the-middle attacks and any attacker would be able to view the information being sent to the server. Use of a HTTPS request would mitigate this attack.

title: Privacy Considerations for service endpoints
body:
Prior to PING and linked to our many [layering discussions in SDS](https://github.com/decentralized-identity/secure-data-store/issues/80), our Privacy Considerations section and [10.4 Herd Privacy](https://w3c.github.io/did-core/#herd-privacy) in particular might be reviewed. 





[5.7](https://w3c.github.io/did-core/#service-endpoints) says: "One of the primary purposes of a DID document is to enable discovery of service endpoints." The Privacy Considerations section does a good job of discussing correlation risks in general but is light on the risks and mitigations related to service endpoints.





As I understand it, the relationship between pseudonymous DIDs, herd immunity, and service endpoints implies that, in all "Privacy by Design" use-cases, the number of service endpoints SHOULD be one in order to reduce the risk of correlation and enhance the effectiveness of Herd Privacy.





[Requesting Parties](https://github.com/w3c/did-core/issues/248#issuecomment-645486701) who discover a pseudonymous DID by whatever means, especially a search of "de-identified" metadata in various directories, SHOULD be directed to some kind of **consent-based access control service** with a minimum loss of entropy. This is especially important for DID methods that consider mitigation the GDPR Right to be Forgotten and in light of the fact that GDPR, CCPA, and HIPAA all allow unlimited use of de-identified data with little concern on enforcement of re-identification.





My suggestion would be to enhance the Privacy Considerations section with a discussion of how access control services could be proxied or otherwise "tumbled" by a herd privacy intermediary that could be chosen by the DID controller or data subject independently of the access control service or not. It would then be up to the DID controller to decide whether to use a dumb proxy mechanism like TOR or an access control service that provides herd privacy as the one service endpoint in a pseudonymous DID.

title: GDPR-139 Filtering out offender records that have Word documents
body: Records that have associated Word documents stored within the DB will need special attention, with free text searches to be performed on these documents.  To make progress, we will aim to address this in another phase of work, for now simply filtering them out.

title: Documentation web-site does not respect my privacy
body:
The documentation website https://www.rebar3.org/docs/ is not respecting my privacy: It uses google analytics, imgur and a to of Javascript from readme.io, which is required to read the documentation. Thus google, imgur and readme.io learn which web-sites I'm visiting, and when. Esp.Google is know to profile people - which is a threat to freedom and democray.





Please remove this spyware from the website. Thanks.





Side-note: Given that https://github.com/erlang states "Sweden" as source of origin, this is even worse, as you are violating European Law. The EU GDPR requires *explicit* *consent* prior to processing personal identifiable data.

title: Allow referencing environment variables in the configuration
body:
Add support for setting an environment variable named `GDPR_DUMP_DATABASE_PASSWORD`.





It takes the precedence over the value from the configuration file (if any).


This allows to set the database password from shell scripts.

title: SPAM From CIRCUITHUB !
body:
I am reporting this as an issue to inform contributers about the abuse of the contact information left in the project commit information.   This is almost certainly not the responsibility of KiCost, Kitspace or Github.





I was contacted by Circuithub on the address used for my commits to invite me to use their services.


In Europe this is against GDPR regulations.





I filed a request with them regarding my personal data and they replied.  I am not expecting to received more detailed information about the company that provided them with this information that was collected based on their explicit request.





I now have to check how to remove this information from my git commits and I have already taken action to disable the email address I used.

title: Facebook Pixel Support
body:
Hi guys, been on a bit of a wild goose chase trying to get Facebook Pixel up and running, I'm probably doing something silly...





First up, I don't see a banner, initially I took it that I need to implement that myself and simply set `gatsby-gdpr-facebook-pixel` once the user accepts.  So I decided to use `react-cookie-consent` and set this cookie on the `onAccept` event, works to a point but I need to refresh the page for the pixel to load so I tried to send a `window.fbq("consent", "grant")` but no luck.





So looking through the issues, I see that I should see a banner, I don't, but the further question would be, can I change the appearance of this banner? I can't see anything in the docs/code.


https://github.com/andrezimpel/gatsby-plugin-gdpr-cookies/issues/4#issuecomment-583735299





So if I was to use `react-cookie-consent` to implement the banner, how would I initialise the pixel on accept?





Hope that all makes sense.

title: GDPR? What impact does it have?
body:
As far as I can tell, to be compliant with GDPR this site needs to:





* have a privacy policy/notice which includes:


  * What personal information you collect


  * How and why you collect it


  * How you use it


  * How you secure it


  * Any third parties with access to it


  * If you use cookies


  * How users can control their data


  * Who collects the data


  * What data is being collected


  * The legal basis for processing the data


  * Who, if anyone, the data be shared with


  * How the information will be used


  * How long will the data be stored


  * What rights users have to their data


  * How users can raise a complaint





The privacy policy should address these eight rights: https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-data-protection/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/individual-rights/





* get user consent before storing any personal information—for this app, that would mean getting consent before signing up.





> In order to participate in the AF GANG Mail Exchange, we require:


> * your email address;


> * your name; and


> * your postal address.


>


> Your name and address will be shared with one other user for each exchange is drawn. For example, if you participate in two exchanges, two people will be sent your name and address.


>


> If you don't provide us with those details, we're not able to have you take part in the mail exchange. Sorry!

















Sources:





* https://morweb.org/Post/37/3-Steps-to-GDPR-Compliance-for-Your-Nonprofit-Website

title: Account configuration and validation
body:
## Account Configuration





We should have account configuration settings available in Prebid Server.





In addition to validating that an account (publisher id) is known to the prebid-server, account-specific configurations would be needed to support planned functionality. The Java version has the following per-account configurations, for example:





- eventsEnabled: to control win notification events such as #1202 or video impression tracking #1015


- enforceGdpr


- bannerCacheTtl


- videoCacheTtl


- analyticsSamplingFactor





PBS-Go has a simple yaml accounts list in legacy code, not used for openrtb2 endpoints and with the current definition as a list of strings, only useful for validation. PBS-Java supports a yaml file with a more complex structure, and a database source.





### Implementation





For implementation, supporting the same data sources as PBS-Java could be useful to some extent and the ability to refresh the data in flight is needed as well. The HTTP api source is well suited for this purpose, even more versatile than the database in my opinion. FileFetcher less so (I will create a ticket for separate discussion on this).





I'm willing to take a stab at implementing this. Thoughts ?

title: Additional valid uses for IDP
body:
Small change adding key valid uses for IDPs in terms of knowing the RP at some point.





1. legal obligations - while obtaining End-User Consent/Authorization for sharing information the IDP must disclose the legal grounds as well as the RPs terms of services and establish transparency about the RP receiving information (GDPR perspective)  See also https://github.com/samuelgoto/WebID/blob/master/privacy_threat_model.md#identity-provider-has-a-relationship-with-the-rp 


2. out-of-band privacy controls - IDPs typically offer users out-of-band controls (from a browsers perspective). Users using IDPs with many RPs (which in turn process information from them, access APIs, ...) need a consolidated view/control

title: Add support for filtering Nginx logs
body: Because there are GDPR requirements on sending Personally Identifiable Information (PII) to third party services, we want to make sure we are not logging any PII that gets sent as query params in requests. This PR uses the [Nginx JS Module](https://www.nginx.com/blog/introduction-nginscript/) to check query params in the incoming requests, and filter out any that match the Email regex. I see this as a first step in supporting log filtering, if needed I think we can expand it and formalise an API around the JS modules, to make it easier to add new filters or instance specific filters. But I would rather wait until we have a clearer understanding of what we would need before trying to solve that problem 😄 . ## How to Test **Testing with filtering enabled** 1. Clone the branch 1. Run `docker-compose -f docker-compose.test.yml build` 1. Run `docker-compose -f docker-compose.test.yml up` 1. Using the browser (or curl) go to http://localhost:50132/?email=john.smith@smith.com 1. In the nginx logs you should see `email=[EMAIL FILTERED]`, like the screenshots **Testing with filtering disabled** 1. Stop the docker containers session if it's still running 1. Change the [`FILTER_LOGS` param](https://github.com/degica/barcelona/pull/601/files#diff-71027439e4e13f5ebb931f5ea1f97b66R14) to "false" (or remove it entirely) 1. Run `docker-compose -f docker-compose.test.yml up` 1. Using the browser (or curl) go to http://localhost:50132/?email=john.smith@smith.com 1. In the nginx logs you should see `email=john.smith@smith.com` ## Screenshots **with `FILTER_LOGS=true`** **with `FILTER_LOGS=false`**

title: Amplitude Cookies lifetime are not GDPR compliant
body:
Amplitude default cookie configuration doesn't respect GDPR, as it states cookies tracking users should live no longer than 13 months (according to French CNIL) and 12 months according to GDPR itself (https://gdpr.eu/cookies/#:~:text=All%20persistent%20cookies%20have%20an,you%20do%20not%20take%20action.), while those created by the JS SDK live for 10 years by default.





I strongly suggest you change the default lifetime of cookies created by Amplitude SDKs to match this requirement (12 months). Here is a screenshot of cookies created by Amplitude JS SDK at https://nrn-v2-mst-aptd-at-lcz-sty-c1-amplitude-g.vercel.app/fr


 


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3807458/87974508-772f1400-caca-11ea-8534-411f2c95316e.png)








This single violation of the GDPR makes Amplitude non GDPR compliant (according to my attorney).





Also, I haven't found any way of changing that behavior through configuration of the JS SDK at https://developers.amplitude.com/docs/javascript-sdk-reference, and I suggest such option gets added for people who'd have even stricter rules regarding cookies (or to gracefully handle any future change in the GDPR itself, regarding this particular matter).

title: New IAB TCFv2.0 LiveRamp CMP live - revenue and CPM drops
body: Hi, I'm new to github and have run out of ideas on why I've seen a significant drop in prebid revenue and cpm since we released LiveRamp's CMP on our site earlier this week. We're running Prebid version 3.18.0 We released the Liveramp CMP across our site (cv-library.co.uk) at the beginning of the week. Since then I have seen Prebid revenue drop off a cliff and both Google AdX and Adsense CPM's have dropped by half. When I debug Prebid on the site (e.g. https://www.cv-library.co.uk/accountancy-jobs?pbjs_debug=true) I can see the CMP load, when I consent I then see the consent string present. I can also see that on the surface it appears we are providing the consent string in our Bid requests to partners (see attached sshot). There are other prebid calls on the page (different versions) that relate to other partners loaded in our ad server which I'm not too concerned about for the time being. It looks like both the GDPR Consent Module and GDPR Enforcement Module are working as expected. What i can't explain is why our Prebid partners have stopped bidding or are bidding at a much lower rate. If anyone can provide any suggestions I'm all ears. First thoughts are: Some sort of Timeout issue CMP is interfering with the bid requests in some way... There is an issue with the Prebid version we are using Under Vendor data the 'cmpVersion' is set to '1' - should this not be '2' I can see another thread related to Quantcast here that sounds similar to the issue we are having - https://github.com/prebid/Prebid.js/issues/5462 I've contacted Prebid partners and am waiting to hear back as well as discussions with LiveRamp but nothing as yet has presented itself as the potential issue. If anyone can take a look and advise at all I'd be extremely grateful!! Many thanks Matt ## Test page It's on the live site but ads and Prebid calls can be seen on all Job posting pages - e.g. https://www.cv-library.co.uk/accountancy-jobs

title: Feature Request: Secure Erase | Remove-Item
body:
## Summary of the new feature/enhancement





As an IT-Administrator I need to delete files according to GDPR. In a lot of cases it is required to make sure that a deleted file cannot be restored, so I need a way to securely erase files in Powershell. 


The cmdlet should be native in powershell, so you don't have to install any additional software





## Proposed technical implementation details (optional)





I think the implementation should be in the original Remove-Item cmdlet. If I add the argument "-Secure", I want the file to be overridden.


Override-Content: The most basic function would be to override all bytes the file uses on the harddisk with zeroes. In other cases it may be required to override the bytes with random values.


Repetitions: It may also be required to enter a number of repetions for the override if one override is not sufficient.


Example: Remove-Item C:\Users\Tobias\Secret -Recurse -Secure random -Rep 3


^--> This cmd should securely erase C:\Users\Tobias\Secret with all subfolders and files by overriding all sectors that contain content of the affected files on the volume three times with a random sequence and of course remove the entry in the MFT as before.

title: Export useful sanitizing functions: printWithReducedWhitespace, hideStringAndNumericLiterals and hideLiterals
body:
GraphQL execution requests can include PII. At Indeed we have need of a mechanism to sanitize requests of PII in order to maintain GDPR and CCPA requirements. I'm certain many other companies have this need, and expect this to also be useful for companies requiring HIPPA compliance.





The existing hideStringAndNumericLiterals and hideLiterals functions look to be well suited for this purpose. Here I've exported these functions, along with printWithReducedWhitespace which is a nice companion to both. I've updated the existing test for `hideLiterals` to cover more scenarios and added a test for `hideStringAndNumericLiterals`.





- [x] Update CHANGELOG.md\* with your change (include reference to issue & this PR)


- [x] Make sure all of the significant new logic is covered by tests


- [x] Rebase your changes on master so that they can be merged easily


- [x] Make sure all tests and linter rules pass

title: #109 Add proper cookie consent, show content conditionally, remove unnecessary cookies
body:
This PR adds a proper, hopefully GDPR compliant cookie consent. 

The third party tool used is cookiebot.com - account is registered on frie.p@correlaid.org, password is stored in bitwarden. 
the free version of cookiebot scans once per month for new cookies. this should give us enough time to adapt in case we add new cookies through third party services (e.g. calendly adds a cookie).

This PR also removes unnecessary cookies such as for the correlaidx navbar and for twitter.com (we now use the hugo embedding which does not rely on cookies). The latter is not yet reflected in the cookie consent because this was updated after the initial scan. 

The calendly widget is now only shown when the marketing (renamed to "social media features and third party services") cookies are accepted. otherwise we have a button that leads to the calendly website.

title: Interpretation of empty publisherTC
body:
How should an empty publisherTC be interpreted? 





By default CMPs sent an empty  **PublisherTC**.


But, according to [Publisher TC](https://github.com/InteractiveAdvertisingBureau/GDPR-Transparency-and-Consent-Framework/blob/master/TCFv2/IAB%20Tech%20Lab%20-%20Consent%20string%20and%20vendor%20list%20formats%20v2.md#publisher-purposes-transparency-and-consent) for **PubPurposesConsent**, valid values for each purpose are 0 or 1. Empty value is not documented.





Should that be interpreted as no-consent (ie. empty = 0) or should empty values should be ignored? 


Can the documentation be clarified on this use-case?





Thanks.

title: TCFv2 CMP
body:
## Why are you doing this?





This PR enabled the TCFv2 compliant CMP for all non-US users, this is implemented using https://www.npmjs.com/package/@guardian/consent-management-platform.





[**Trello Card**](https://trello.com/c/AH8m5Soz/3242-upgrade-to-tcfv2-cmp-on-supporttheguardiancom)





## Changes





- Upgrade `@guardian/consent-management-platform` to v4 (TCFv2 compliant support).


- Update `page.js` to call `cmp.init` using the new interface exposed by `@guardian/consent-management-platform`  v4.


- Update `thirdPartyTrackingConsent.js` to use the new `onConsentChange` function exposed by `@guardian/consent-management-platform`.  `onConsentChange` takes a callback that it executes with consent state, passed as the parameter `state`.  The value of `state` will differ when in CCPA mode (US users) and TCFv2 mode (everyone else), so the callback determines which mode we're in, and returns either "OptedIn" or "OptedOut". There is no longer an "Unset" (null) state, so this has been removed from the code base.


- Remove logic used to read/write the `GU_TK` cookie from thirdPartyTrackingConsent.js`.


- Remove the old-CMP component (`ConsentBanner.jsx`), it's associated styles.


- I've removed the `ccpaEnabled` switch, this was in place to fallback to the old-CMP if necessary when releasing the CCPA  CMP, I don't think there's value in this now as we're removing the old-CMP in this PR.





## Screenshots





![tcvf2_mobile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1590704/89309412-4d015880-d66b-11ea-887e-74b26e63f99a.gif)





![tcvf2_desktop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1590704/89309430-4ffc4900-d66b-11ea-955f-5cf7fb4594b6.gif)

title: User Profiles (and Organizations) Spec
body:
### Overview


User profiles stores personal information, but only a UserID and Email is required. These profiles can for a person, or for an organization to allow participation as a group.


#### Details:


- **User profile:** The current version of Codalab v2 does not allow users to edit their profile. This functionality will be implemented (Figure 3). Integration of user accounts on different components (CodaBench, Codalab, ChaGrade) will be supported if needed. User’s profiles will include (* means mandatory; to protect anonymity, only a contact email is required to identify users)


- **Organizations as User:** This will allow users to organize competitions and participate in them as a group. However, being a member of an organization is not mandatory to organize/participate a challenge/benchmark. This will also allow the platform to give credits to organization members for organizing competitions or participating in them (in their visible profile). To claim organizing a challenge or participating in it, an organization member will need to have been a member of that organization at least some time during the active period of the competition. This feature could replace both the notion of teams and of admins. To avoid sharing passwords, a member of an organization, logged in with his own personal ID, could switch to any organization he/she is a member of. 


- **Meta-users** (platform administrators) will be granted the right to impersonate users. 





### Tasks


- User ID *: cannot be changed


- Display name *: To be shown on leaderboard and profile page; by default, show the user ID; this can be changed


- Contact Person Email *: can be changed


- Contact Person First Name: optional


- Contact Person Last Name: optional


- Contact Person Title: optional


- Affiliation or Organization Name: optional


- Picture: optional (personal photo or organization logo)


- Description: optional


- Links to websites and social media: optional


- is_organization? Check-box


  - Editable list of current organization members: provide Codalab IDs of organization 


members


  - Non-editable list of former organization members (and dates start-end)


  - Choice of benchmarks and competitions co-organized to show on profile (check/uncheck) any organization member of a competition can add a competition in this list


  - Choice of benchmarks and competitions in which participated and rank/number of 


participants – any organization member of a competition can add a competition in this list


- Opt-in/out to receive emails (to respect GDPR).


### Discussion points


- Have base Profile object extended by User and Organization objects. Users and Organizations would share a lot of features, but would have more differentiation.

title: Fine grained data collection
body:
This replaces #46. The PR was originally directed at handling personal data. Now, it's a bit more general.





Here, I've changed the `allowed_schemas` trait to explicitly list all event properties that should be recorded based on their name or category. This can be used to filter-out personal data.





Summary of the changes made:


* `allowed_schemas` can now be a dictionary describing *what* data to keep when recording an event (see example below).


* schemas require a `categories` field under each property. This field can be used to group properties.


* `unrestricted` is a special category that means the named property will always be recorded when that event is recorded.





## How it works





`allowed_schemas` is now a nested dictionary where the keys are the schema IDs, and the values are dictionaries with two optional fields, `properties` and `categories`, describing the properties in the event that should be recorded.





As an example, 


```python


allowed_schemas = {


    "uri.to.schema": {


        "allowed_properties": ["name", "email"],


        "allowed_categories": ["personal-information"]


    }


}








c.EventLog.allowed_schemas=allowed_schemas


```


When the `uri.to.schema` event is recorded, it will include the properties, `email` and `name`, **and** any other properties with the category label `personal-information`. All other properties will not be recorded.





## Personal data





While this PR doesn't specifically address personal data, it provides a mechanism to filter out personal data. For example, properties can be labeled with categories like `hippa`, `gdpr`, `pii`, etc. to make filtering under different regimes possible.

title: Add create policy page buttons
body:
Okay, not sure why I thought this wasn't doable, must've been a bad brain day...





This PR:





* adds buttons to the settings page to create the privacy or cookie policy pages


* these buttons are built via a helper function [`render_secondary_button`](https://github.com/humanmade/altis-consent/wiki/Altis-Consent-Public-Functions#settingsrender_secondary_button)


* when these buttons are clicked, we hijack the `$_POST` handling to run the logic to create the pages


* the code is based on [how core does it](https://github.com/WordPress/WordPress/blob/master/wp-admin/options-privacy.php#L49-L79) but abstracted a bit so we can reuse the same code for both the cookie and privacy policy pages (or other pages that could be added later


* adds a new `cookie-policy.php` which is where the default cookie policy page content is handled


* this policy content is based on [the EU cookie policy content](https://github.com/Really-Simple-Plugins/complianz-gdpr/blob/1ffaff06cbe3c70758f7dd81fc40de257f3d8b0c/config/documents/cookie-policy-eu.php) in the [Complianz](https://github.com/Really-Simple-Plugins/complianz-gdpr) plugin.


* new filters to control various bits of this functionality (all documented in the Filters documentation) including changing the content of the cookie policy page.





A filter exists to disable Gutenberg support for the new cookie policy page that's created which defaults to `true` (Gutenberg enabled)





### Screenshots





Updated settings page


![Screen Shot 2020-08-28 at 4 15 37 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/991511/91619595-b878d600-e94a-11ea-995f-60ac3303fe54.png)





Generated Cookie Policy page:


![Screen Shot 2020-08-28 at 4 15 21 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/991511/91619619-cdee0000-e94a-11ea-94ff-9a8e7b3b734d.png)

title: Gdpr support
body:
There is [GDPR support in .NET Core 3.1](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/gdpr?view=aspnetcore-3.1), this update allows you to take advantage.





It is enabled by setting the `CookieConsentEnabled` to true in the Site.Config file.





This is backward compatible, in that if the setting does not exist in your config file it is set to false by default.

title: Encrypt & Decrypt Emails In The Database
body:
There should be a way to encrypt/decrypt emails in the database because emails fall into GDPR / PII / Privacy laws. Perhaps using a database setting like NEWSFEED_EMAIL_ENCRYPT = True|False would enable/disable this feature. This way if your database was ever stolen/hacked, the attacker would not be able to see the emails. 





But If someone changes this setting later on the user would probably need to do some sort of data migrations. https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.1/howto/writing-migrations/ which is not really desirable. Unless it can somehow get built into the app?





SELECT SQL queries and django get() should be able to view the decrypted emails. 





Some ideas would be to do something like django-fernet-fields which uses the SECRET_KEY to do both the encryption and decryption. Or if you are using postgres, do something like django-pgcrypto-fields which uses a postgres pgcrypto extension.

title: Layout: AsyncLoad GdprBanner in LayoutLoggedOut
body:
In #38599 we started loading `GdprBanner` asynchronously in the logged-in layout component. This PR is doing it for the logged-out layout component, and that allows us to remove it from the main entry point. This reduces the main entry point (gzipped) by 0.5%.





#### Changes proposed in this Pull Request





* Layout: AsyncLoad `GdprBanner` in `LayoutLoggedOut`.





#### Testing instructions





* Delete the `sensitive_pixel_option` cookie if you have it.


* Go to  http://calypso.localhost:3000?flags=gdpr-banner


* If you're not in a GDPR-enabled country, you will have to enable `isCurrentUserMaybeInGdprZone` to return `true`.


* Verify you can still see the GDPR banner.

title: JetEngine – forms – Integration with Mailerlite
body:
JetEngine Forms (profile builder) has limited integrations with 3rd party mailing list services. Unless you have a paid Zapier account, then users are limited to 100 zaps/month, which is potentially not enough for a small–mid-sized membership site. And even with Zapier, it introduces an unnecessary 3rd step between JetEngine and a mailing list service. And the inbuilt 'send email' function is limited in terms of design options, which doesn't make a great impression on new users.

Therefore, I request further integrations with a wider range of mailing list services, removing the need for Zapier. My personal request is for Mailerlite, since they have a more flexible free pricing plan than MailChimp and offer good GDPR solutions for EU-based websites/customers/members. 

Adding more integrations, will immediately ease the workflow in JetEngine when registering new users or subscribing them to mailing lists. It will also provide greater flexibility and choice to JetEngine users, when deciding which mailing list service to use and when deciding whether to buy JetEngine or another membership plugin. For example, they may need to transfer existing mailing lists over to JetEngine profile builder and might not want the added complication/limitation of using Zapier. This will make JetEngine a more competitive choice compared with other site-membership plugins.

Elementor already has a wide range of 3rd party mailing list vendors for their form widgets. But this cannot be used by most JetEngine users when managing new user/member registrations. This use case is particularly crucial for JetEngine subscribers.

title: Removed misleading sentence on User Delete
body:
# Pull Request/Issue Resolution





**Description of Change:**


Clients were concerned that our documentation stated "users’ associated event data will still exist" even after a delete request from a GDPR compliance point of view. This sentence was misleading since a user's events are actually deleted entirely, it is merely aggregate event counts that remain unaltered. This is already covered in above alert box and explained in a FAQ, hence I'm proposing to remove this sentence to avoid further misunderstandings.





Closes #**ISSUE_NUMBER_HERE**

title: Report Generation not working
missing privacy api
body:
Moodle uses a privacy API for GDPR compliance to allow plugins to specify how they deal with user data. Your plugin doesn't appear to store any user data so you should be able to implement the simple null provider class.





Sites that use continuous integration processes will not be able to use your plugin because Moodle runs unit tests which check to see if all extra plugins include the privacy class.





More information on the privacy class is here:


https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Privacy_API

title: Doesn't block the stuff as effectively as expected
body:
### Describe the issue





I decided to turn off uBO and try out AdNauseam.


The config and the lists setup in uBO and AdNauseam are identical


So I was expecting AdNauseam to be hiding crap as good as uBO.


In practice, it turned to be not as expected, and the following crap started being visible after I switched:


- Popups and overlays related to cookies / gdpr & terms of use / privacy terms / privacy notice / such stuff on all websites.


- Advertised search results on Startpage.


- Maybe something more that I no longer remember.





Doubt that "Your settings" and "Your filter lists" play any role here, as mentioned they are identical in uBO and AdNauseam, and uBO cuts all the bad stuff very well.





Am I doing something wrong?


Or is it an expected behavior of AdNauseam cutting the stuff not as effectively as uBO?


In case of the latter, I should keep both uBO and AdNauseam active, and configure them in a way that they have no match in active settings and lists (active in the former, disabled in the latter), to cut the crap and in the same time let AdNauseam do its mission, are there any recommendations on how to do it the best / most practical way?





### Screenshot in which the issue can be seen


.





### Steps for anyone to reproduce the issue


.





### Your settings

title: Require documenting policy in the codebase (as part of 'bundle policy and code')
body:
Right now, we often suggest linking to a policy published on an external website (for example a public org's own website).





This can become a vulnerability for the codebase, especially with a codebase built for one org and then genericized - that one org's policy documentation can easily change (especially after a political change). The risk is a dead link and a codebase that's no longer Standard compliant.





I would suggest a standard policy file that copies the policy and links to the original source with a date (like we do here: 


https://about.publiccode.net/activities/tool-management/docusign.html#privacy-and-gdpr).





This can be added to with new replicators and their policies.

title: [MRG] Jail
body:
As discussed on Slack, I've implemented a prototype "jail" idea for review/comments. I'm not sure if this is a good way of solving these problems, so I'd like some feedback on what people think. It feels kind of convoluted and especially tacking it on now to the authentication system (that assumed a 2-state model) makes it a bit awkward (there's now 3 states: not logged in, logged in, and logged in but jailed).





This makes it possible for a user to be authenticated while not being able to use the main APIs, but only a subset, the "jailed" ones. This is useful if:





1. The user has not finished signing up (e.g. has not finished adding a location)


2. The user has not accepted TOS/GDPR/etc


3. The user is banned, but we'd like to show them something nicer than a "you're banned" at login





It makes it easy to add requirements, e.g. update a privacy policy and make sure everyone has agreed to them, or add required fields to a user profile.





This is also missing tests.

title: Adds user attributes to HotJar
body:
#### Changes proposed in this Pull Request





* Adds user attributes to Hotjar.


* The userId has been set to a random number.


* The attributes that have been added are `hasPaidDomain` and `selectedPlan`.





#### Testing instructions





<!--


Add as many details as possible to help others reproduce the issue and test the fix.


"Before / After" screenshots can also be very helpful when the change is visual.


-->





* Disable the "Do Not Track" setting in your browser. In Chrome:


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5436027/99255404-e3801100-2839-11eb-9bc3-25622c02f4cf.png)

* Make sure the gdpr cookie is set to yes ( sensitive_pixel_option = yes )

* Go through the signup flow, after the plans step the survey should be shown on the processing screen.


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5436027/99253015-fa246900-2835-11eb-8fea-953daa8b2614.png)


* Answer the question and check the Hotjar dashboard to see if user attributes have been collected correctly.

🆕 Software Suggestion | Databunker
body:
## Basic Information





**Name:** Databunker


**Category:** software/cloud/


**URL:** https://databunker.org/





## Description





Databunker is a GDPR compliant user store service for Web and mobile apps. Databunker is a combination of several software concepts build together to provide PII storage and **privacy by design** out of the box:





* Personal identifiable information (PII) storage and vault


* Secure session storage for web applications


* Privacy portal for customers


* Application backend server


* DPO management tool


* Tokenization service


* Secret sauce





Databunker provides Nodejs examples for easy onboarding:





https://github.com/securitybunker/hello-nodejs-passport-js-magic-link-databunker











## Why I am making the suggestion





Originally I developed Databunker to help me to store customer data in a full GDPR compliant way. It grew to be a full-featured solution standing stringent privacy requirements.








## My connection with the software





I am a product author. Contact me at yuli@privacybunker.io for any questions.





- [x] I will keep the issue up-to-date if something I have said changes or I remember a connection with the software.

body: This PR adds authentication to the GDPR API. Query and delete operations require that the profile belongs to the user of the API token. The GDPR API also requires specific scopes for query and delete operations.

RIGHTS.PRINCIPLES: cookies, right to erasure, right to access
CONCERNS.coder.1: User rights functionality, Cookies preferences, Law information page/policy
CONCERN.FINAL2: User rights functionality, Cookies preferences, Law information page/policy

title: Temporarily disable Google Analytics
body:
Using Google Analytics without a consent banner like we do now is not GDPR-compliant. Unfortunately, there's no built-in way to show a cookie banner in Docusaurus. See also this [open issue](https://docusaurus-2.netlify.app/feedback/p/cookie-consent-component).





This might be a small site, but I still think we should be careful in GDPR compliance and respect users' privacy. So with this PR, I've disabled Google Analytics until either Docusaurus adds a cookie banner or we add one ourselves.

title: consent string with no consent but cookie set
body:
Hi,





I am calling the setuid endpoint with a consent string which contains no consent information at all about my vendor id, but a cookie is dropped anyway. I did not changed the gdpr.enabled value so it's true by default according to config.go. In my pbs.yaml I have these settings about gdpr : 


```


gdpr:


        host_vendor_id: 791


        timeouts_ms.init_vendorlist_fetches: 1000


        timeouts_ms.active_vendorlist_fetch: 1000


```


I am not so sure about the effets of these defaults params in config.go : 


```


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.purpose1.enabled", true)


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.purpose2.enabled", true)


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.purpose4.enabled", true)


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.purpose7.enabled", true)


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.special_purpose1.enabled", true)


        v.SetDefault("gdpr.tcf2.purpose_one_treatement.enabled", true)

```


Does it means that it forces these purpose to true regardless of the consent string received ?

GameSpot.com - Modal overlay / Blocked videos (EasyList Cookie List / Fanboy's Annoyance List) [GDPR]
body:
### Affected site:


`https://www.gamespot.com/`





### Issue:


Videos won't play / grey modal overlay.





### Example:


`https://www.gamespot.com/videos/this-little-nightmares-ii-gameplay-will-give-you-anxiety/2300-6454627/`





### Screenshot:


Not needed, as the problem is obvious.





### Problem filters:


* **EasyList Cookie List**


* **Fanboy's Annoyance List**





### Problem rules:


```


###onetrust-banner-sdk


@@||geolocation.onetrust.com/cookieconsentpub/$script


```


(The first rule causes the issue because of the second rule, and vice versa)





### Related issue:


A similar problem uccurs @ **CBSNews.com**:


https://github.com/easylist/easylist/issues/7318/





### Possible fix:


```


- @@||geolocation.onetrust.com/cookieconsentpub/$script





+ ||geolocation.onetrust.com/cookieconsentpub/$script,domain=cbsnews.com|gamespot.com


+ @@||geolocation.onetrust.com/cookieconsentpub/$script,domain=~cbsnews.com|~gamespot.com


```





### Temporary fixes:


For ABP (allowing the cookie consent popup):


`gamespot.com#@##onetrust-banner-sdk`





For uBO (blocking the geolocation script):


`||geolocation.onetrust.com/cookieconsentpub/$script,important,domain=gamespot.com`


(@okiehsch: I guess this falls outside of scope, for any of the uBO Filters?)





--





### System info:


* OS/version: Windows 8.1 Pro (x64)


* Browser/version: Pale Moon v29.0.1 (x64)


* Adblock Extension/version: uBlock Origin v1.16.4.28 (XUL)

title: [JIRA] User search required parameters additions
body:
The GDPR changes to the REST API have removed the username parameter from the user search endpoint and now requires either a query, accountId or property parameter be specified otherwise the request will fail. According to the API documentation, a query and accountId cannot both be provided otherwise the request will fail.





This PR brings the Python Jira.user_find_by_user_string() method into alignment with the REST API's post-GDPR changes. It also updates the associated documentation per the contribution guidelines. I tested the functionality against Jira Cloud that my company uses and it worked as expected.





Fixes #726. See that issue for more details. This method is broken until this PR is merged.

title: [Bug] Media notification shows music is paused when it's playing
body: ## Steps to reproduce 1. Open https://fm.tuba.pl/radio/Radio+Z%C5%82ote+Przeboje 2. Accept gdpr form (blue button) 3. Hit "WŁĄCZ RADIO" button (with play symbol on the right) 4. Wait until music starts playing ### Expected behavior Media notification should show that music is playing and offer to pause it. Media symbol (on tab list) should also show that music is playing and offer to pause it. ### Actual behavior Both media notification in android notifications and media symbol on tab list, show that music is paused and offers to play it. When clicking either of them, they both disappear, while music continues to play (both screenshots are taken while music is playing): ### Device information * Device vendor / model and Android version: Samsung Galaxy J7 2017, android 8.1 * Firefox for Android version: 85.1.3 ┆Issue is synchronized with this [Jira Task](https://mozilla-hub.atlassian.net/browse/FNXV2-9802)

title: NowSecure dynamic analysis: Cookie "Secure" Misconfiguration Can Lead to Web Vulnerabilies
body:
### Summary

Cookies were found to have the "Secure" flag  set to false. If a cookie is not marked as “Secure,” it may be transmitted over an insecure connection whether or not the session with the host is secure. In other words, it may be be transmitted over an HTTP connection. If an attacker can intercept a cookie intended to be transmitted over a secure channel, the attacker may be able to get access to secure session tokens or other authentication information.

### Recommendation

It is recommended to enable the "secure" flag to instruct the browser to only send the cookie if the request is sent using a secure channel.

More information on this type of vulnerability can be found at: https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SecureFlag#Setting_the_Secure_Flag and https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly#Mitigating_the_Most_Common_XSS_attack_using_HttpOnly

There are multiple ways to enable this, one of which is to set it within the
response header:

Set-Cookie: <name>=<value>[; <Max-Age>=<age>]
[; expires=<date>][; domain=<domain_name>]
[; path=<some_path>][; secure][; HttpOnly]

The context table below provides the source and the type of cookie which was found to be vulnerable.

### Risk and Regulatory Information

Severity: medium
CVSS: 5.3

- CWE: [614](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/614.html)
- FISMA MED: [SC-8 TRANSMISSION CONFIDENTIALITY AND INTEGRITY](https://nvd.nist.gov/800-53/Rev4/control/SC-8)
- Risk OWASP: [Mobile Top 10: M7-Client Code Quality](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Mobile_Top_10_2016-M7-Poor_Code_Quality)
- GDPR: [Risks violating Article 25](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-25-gdpr/), [Risks violating Article 32](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-32-gdpr/)
- FFIEC: [May violate D3.PC.Am.Int.7](https://www.ffiec.gov/pdf/cybersecurity/FFIEC_CAT_May_2017.pdf)
- PCI: [May violate requirement 4.1](https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/document_library?document=pci_dss)
- HIPAA: [May violate §164.312(e)(1): Standard: Transmission security.](https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/ocr/privacy/hipaa/administrative/securityrule/techsafeguards.pdf?language=es)
- CCPA: [Risks violating CCPA: exfiltration, theft, or disclosure of PII](http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=CIV&sectionNum=1798.150.)

### Application

- Platform: ios
- Package: com.vanguard.app

See more detail in the [NowSecure Report](https://lab.nws-stg-west.nowsecure.io/app/543cbabc-150f-11eb-80b5-0b34a267bc92/assessment/1614577032335#finding-cookie_without_secure_flag)

title: NowSecure dynamic analysis: App is Using Outdated or Insecure Cryptography
body:
### Summary

The application was found to use weak cryptographic algorithms during app runtime. These methods are usually easily reverse engineered, so the data is not really protected very well. An attacked with access to the encrypted data could easily see the data that was obfuscated.##Evaluation Criteria
It is a best practice not to use insecure methods to encrypt data. However, not all companies require this. The context table below should be evaulated against the standards for the app. Also, please note there is a separate finding specifically for sensitive data being encrypted using these methods.

### Recommendation

Change to using algrythms that are secure. Guidance can be found [for Android](https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/security/cryptography) and [from Apple](https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/Security/Conceptual/cryptoservices/GeneralPurposeCrypto/GeneralPurposeCrypto.html).

For more guidance on best practices in picking strong cryptography, please see OWASP's
[Cryptographic Storage Cheat_Sheet](https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Cryptographic_Storage_Cheat_Sheet.html).',

### Risk and Regulatory Information

Severity: low
CVSS: 3.7

- CWE: [312](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/312.html)
- ioXt: [SI111](null)
- FISMA MED: [SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST](https://nvd.nist.gov/800-53/Rev4/control/SC-28)
- Risk OWASP: [Mobile Top 10: M2-Insecure Data Storage](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Mobile_Top_10_2016-M2-Insecure_Data_Storage)
- GDPR: [Risks violating Article 25](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-25-gdpr/), [Risks violating Article 32](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-32-gdpr/)
- FFIEC: [May violate D3.PC.Am.A.1](https://www.ffiec.gov/pdf/cybersecurity/FFIEC_CAT_May_2017.pdf)
- PCI: [May violate requirement 3.1 through 3.4](https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/document_library?document=pci_dss)
- HIPAA: [May violate §164.312(a)(1): Standard: Access control.](https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/ocr/privacy/hipaa/administrative/securityrule/techsafeguards.pdf?language=es)
- CCPA: [Risks violating CCPA: exfiltration, theft, or disclosure of PII](http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=CIV&sectionNum=1798.150.)
- CWE Top 25: [2019 CWE Top 25 Most Dangerous Software Errors](https://cwe.mitre.org/top25/archive/2019/2019_cwe_top25.html)

### Application

See more detail in the [NowSecure Report](https://lab.nws-stg-west.nowsecure.io/app/f305ebb4-fe17-11ea-80b5-47637d98f561/assessment/1614663728623#finding-ipa_weak_crypto_methods)

title: NowSecure dynamic analysis: Vendor ID Stored Insecurely On Device
body:
### Summary

The information specified has been found within local application folders or external storage locations on the device. Data written to device storage can be accessed through several attack vectors.  An attacker who is able to access the charging port may be able to access this data if the user acknowledges the trust or with a rooted/jailbroken device. Often, data backup utilities can also export local files with its backup and, if not encrypted, can be then accessed by an attacker. While malware is also a concern, it is less common than attacks concerning physical device access. If these values are exposed they can be used to track and phish users, access their account, or circumvent protections within the app.

### Recommendation

Sensitive data should not be stored in local app files without the right protection level and unencrypted. It is highly recommended to encrypt all locally stored sensitive data using a strong encryption algorithm. It is also recommended to set the strongest possible data protection level on the file containing the sensitive data. Review the data protection level(s) set on the file(s) listed here and ensure that they are either `NSFileProtectionComplete` for complete protection or `NSFileProtectionCompleteUntilFirstUserAuthentication` to be protected until the user first authenticates to the device. Details and code snippets can be found at  [https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/protecting_the_user_s_privacy/encrypting_your_app_s_files](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/protecting_the_user_s_privacy/encrypting_your_app_s_files)

The context table below gives the location on the device that the specified information was stored insecurely.

### Risk and Regulatory Information

Severity: low
CVSS: 2.3

- CWE: [312](https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/312.html)
- FISMA MED: [SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST](https://nvd.nist.gov/800-53/Rev4/control/SC-28)
- Risk OWASP: [Mobile Top 10: M2-Insecure Data Storage](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Mobile_Top_10_2016-M2-Insecure_Data_Storage)
- GDPR: [Risks violating Article 25](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-25-gdpr/), [Risks violating Article 32](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-32-gdpr/)
- FFIEC: [May violate D3.PC.Am.A.1](https://www.ffiec.gov/pdf/cybersecurity/FFIEC_CAT_May_2017.pdf)
- PCI: [May violate requirement 3.1 through 3.4](https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/document_library?document=pci_dss)
- HIPAA: [May violate §164.312(a)(1): Standard: Access control.](https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/ocr/privacy/hipaa/administrative/securityrule/techsafeguards.pdf?language=es)
- CCPA: [Risks violating CCPA: exfiltration, theft, or disclosure of PII](http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?lawCode=CIV&sectionNum=1798.150.)

title: Wp consent api integration for cf7
body:
Hi @takayukister, 





To comply with privacy laws around the world, reCaptcha [should be blocked](https://complianz.io/google-recaptcha-and-the-gdpr-a-possible-conflict/) until the user has consented to marketing level cookies. We have developed an API, eventually to get merged into WP Core, which offers plugins a method to communicate the consent status to each other: cookie management plugins can set consent, other plugins can set cookies according to the consent status set by the cookie management plugins (currently supported by Complianz and Cookiebot). 





The Consent API proposal for WordPress can be found here:


https://make.wordpress.org/core/2020/04/01/feature-plugin-proposal-wp-consent-api/


Github:


https://github.com/rlankhorst/wp-consent-level-api





To demonstrate how this can work, we have created an integration with the WP Consent API for Contact Form 7. You can view a working example here: https://wpconsentapi.org/contact-form-7/





To enable this feature, installing the WP Consent API is required.





The advantage of using the WP Consent API, is that it will work for each plugin that supports it. 





If the WP Consent API is not active, or if there is no  cookie management plugin, it will function as before. If these are active, consent will be asked if required (opt in, e.g. EU, UK) or it will be possible to opt out (e.g. US, CA).  





Currently the index.js file, which was changed, is not minified, as that will be handled by your release I haven't done this. 





Please let me know if you have any questions about this. 





Merging this branch won't harm existing users, but will offer your users the option to make their site compliant, as required by law in many countries.

title: Double strings?
Reddit: Add info for GDPR-enabled accounts.
body:
After mailing eurepresentative@reddit.com, you get a generic response:


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38327267/112157869-89280000-8bdf-11eb-95ea-e877d452ff98.png)





The link is generic, mailto:-like, what prefills some fields on sending a message to reddit, so why not give it to the user right away.





Since Reddit only claims to comply with actual GDPR-backed requests, I'd say it's better to make a separate entry for it.

title: Show members email addresses to group/topic admin
body: **What is the user story?** The administrator of the group or topic wants to update the email addresses of the members but they only see the user name and user rights but not the email addresses that members have been invited to the group/topic. As a group/topic administrator have the user list anyway (they have invited all members into the group/topic), then users emails could be shown to them. **Which feature needs to be updated and how?** Show group/topic admin members´ email addresses. **Additional information.** Needs input about how it resonates with GDPR :)

title: Implement secure on read routes
body:
Why


=======





The Khan saves player name as plain text on the database, what isn't compliance with the LGPD/GDPR laws. To be compliant with these laws now the Khan accepts a new environment variable `KHAN_SECURITY_ENCRYPTIONKEY` which should be a 32 byte length and will be used to encrypt the player name.





What was done


=======


* Create `security.encryptionKey` on app


* Refactor DAO to segmentize the player serialization field, in a way to concentrate the decryption logic in the `models/player.go`


* Add `util/secure.go` which will hold all encryption logic


* Add tests to `util/secure.go` in `util/secure_test.go`


* Add tests to routes that use the player name

title: Allow setting a GDPR context
body:
Snowplow allows to set a GDPR context for tracking events. Let's add support for that. :) 





To do so, call setGdprContextWith when building the SPTracker.





```swift


builder?.setGdprContextWith(


  gdprContext.basisForProcessing,


  documentId: gdprContext.documentId,


  documentVersion: gdprContext.documentVersion,


  documentDescription: gdprContext.documentDescription


)


```





Don't know exactly how it works on Android, but should be similar.

title: MSSQL [Feature request]: Using remote SQL when restore and backup steps are skipped
body:
We are using pynonymizer to anonymize data in Customer's MS SQL database before it is transferred to our infrastructure for support/development purposes. We cannot do that in our infrastructure because GDPR. We cannot install python on Customer's server. But we have access to the SQL through VPN. 





Solution is to not force using local server only, if only anonymization step is running through using 


```


start_at_step='ANONYMIZE_DB',stop_at_step='ANONYMIZE_DB'


```





I had tested that with success when I removed the check for db_host being None and removing the db_host = "(local)" (for testing purposes without any condition if the ANONYMIZE_DB step is only running).

body:
Resolves #9.





This PR adds the ability to attach a GDPR context to the Snowplow tracker.

title: Liberate users from FLoC tracking on Lichess
body:
This is subjective. Google is looking to replace third-party cookies with a new technology called [Federated Learning of Cohorts](https://web.dev/floc/). In short, this is mainly geared towards targeted advertising by following the user around the web. It's implemented in Chrome, but only outside of the GDPR region, as it's opt-out rather than opt-in.





Users can do it on the browser, but it's fair to say the industry is betting on people not touching the default. We can help them by doing it on the server - because by default, every web server opts people into tracking as of now.


To opt users out, you need a Permissions Policy HTTP header as described [here](https://github.com/WICG/floc#opting-out-of-computation).





I'm not sure the actual server config is hosted here, but I'd be grateful if you would consider opting Lichess out of FLoC, to protect their privacy.

title: Mautic not recognising positive result on Form Field Value campaign conditions with checkbox fields
body:
## Bug Description


Possibly related to the closed issue #5833


Came across this when building out the campaigns for the Mautic Community GDPR / newsletter signup options:





We have a form with a checkbox list, which allows people to select what information they receive from us.





We have a campaign which uses the 'form field value' option to push them into the correct segments based on what is set in the checkbox (a yes value for the field equalling the relevant option:





![screenshot-community eu mautic net-2021 05 13-16_24_06 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2930593/118150615-a96b8280-b40a-11eb-9649-34dbf48b938b.png)





The form submissions are working, but they are not making their way into the correct segments.





In another place I am using a radio button yes/no for GDPR consent, and that part is working correctly - they have a tag applied if they select yes, receive an email, and are unsubscribed/removed if they set no.





![screenshot-community eu mautic net-2021 05 13-16_24_52 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2930593/118150650-b12b2700-b40a-11eb-80be-9dd096b6a234.png)





Perhaps this is an issue with how checkbox or multi-select options are being managed/processed by the form field value option in the campaign workflow?





| Q   | A


| --- | ---


| Mautic version | 3.?


| PHP version | 7.4


| Browser | Chrome





### Steps to reproduce


1. Create a form with a multiselect option field


2. Create a campaign which has conditions based on the value of those fields


3. Add actions on the yes/no for them, so you can check if they are executed (eg change segment or add tag)


4. Fill form, check if the path has been followed

title: GDPR: Don't show user names in polls.
body:
To comply with GDPR there should be an option to do anonymous polls. 


The users don't know that it is visible for the creator of the poll what answer he selects. First of all the user can vote in a way that his answer falls back to him later and if the users know that the creator can see their answers, it is likely that the users don't answer at all or answer differently than if their name would not be shown. So it should be possible to configure bbb that the polls are anonymous.
