title: Clarify that we are requesting a copy in access templates (DE + EN)
body:
In the subject literature, there is a bit of a divide concerning the


relationship between Art. 15(1) and (3) GDPR. Basically, those are the


two differing opinions:





1. The "The controller shall provide a copy of the personal data


   undergoing processing." from Art. 15(3) GDPR mandates how, in


   particular, to give the data subject "access to the personal data"


   according to Art. 15(1) GDPR.





   As such, a request according to Art. 15(1) GDPR includes a request


   for a copy.


2. Art. 15(1) and (3) GDPR are separate rights. A data subject that


   wants a copy of their data explicitly has to request that according


   to Art. 15(3) GDPR.





We believe that by requesting "all personal data concerning me that


you have stored", as we did until now in our access template, it is


obvious that we are in fact requesting a copy of said data.


From countless access requests using our template that we have


submitted ourselves or have been told about by our users, we have also


not seen a single case where a controller interpreted our wording


differently.





However, a user recently kindly forwarded us a response from a data


protection authority to a complaint that did not provide a copy after


they requested access using our template. The authority ruled that it


was not clear from the request that the user in fact asked for a copy


and as such the controller acted correctly.





While we don't agree with the authority's assessment, one of our


primary goals with our request templates is to provide legal certainty


to our users.


As such, we have decided to change the access templates to explicitly


ask for a copy according to Art. 15(3) GDPR. This ensures that there


can be no more misunderstandings in the future and that our users have


a strong legal case for defending against controllers that don't


provide them with a copy of their data.





For reference, this is some of the literature on this topic (only in


German, unfortunately):





* BeckOK DatenschutzR/Schmidt-Wudy, 34. Ed. 1.11.2020, DS-GVO Art. 15


  Rn. 86, beck-online


* Paal/Pauly/Paal, 3. Aufl. 2021, DS-GVO Art. 15 Rn. 23


* Paal/Pauly/Paal, 3. Aufl. 2021, DS-GVO Art. 15 Rn. 33

title: http_authentication_scheme on GET:/api/v1/savings-account/savings-account/{id}
body:
Title: http_authentication_scheme Vulnerability on GET:/api/v1/savings-account/savings-account/{id} Project: Sanity 21st June Description: Assertion Name: HTTP Authentication Scheme ( 1 )

Overview: Authentication is the process of identifying whether a client is eligible to access a resource. The HTTP protocol supports authentication as a means of negotiating access to a secure resource.

The general HTTP authentication framework is used by several authentication schemes. Schemes can differ in security strength and in their availability in client or server software. The server can specify multiple authentication schemes for the client to choose from. The most commonly used API Authentication schemes are

  • Basic
  • API Key
  • OAuth or OAuth 2.0
The "Basic" HTTP authentication scheme transmits credentials as user ID/password pairs, encoded using base64. As the user ID and password are passed over the network as clear text (it is base64 encoded, but base64 is a reversible encoding), the basic authentication scheme is not secure. HTTPS/TLS should be used with basic authentication. Without these additional security enhancements, basic authentication should not be used to protect sensitive or valuable information.

OAuth is the most widespread method used at it delivers a ton of benefits, from ease of use to a federated system module, and most importantly offers scalability of security.

Severity: Not having a secure Authentication Scheme can lead to expose of Sensitive Data and Sensitive Data Exposure is rated at 3rd position in 2017 OWASP Top 10. ( 2 )

Vulnerability Impact: Authentication mechanisms and schemes, if implemented incorrectly, may allow attackers to compromise authentication tokens or to exploit implementation flaws to assume other user's identities temporarily or permanently, compromising system's ability to identify the client/user and may compromise API security overall. The following are some of the consequences.

  • Unnecessary Data Exposure and Data theft.
  • Exposure of Clients data and Personal Identifiable Information.
  • Can be financially devastating to the organization.
  • Non-compliance to data regulations like EU GDPR or local privacy laws.
Remediation: The following may be employed to implement proper authentication scheme.

  • HTTPS/TLS should be used with basic authentication.
  • Classify data processed, stored or transmitted by an application. Identify which data is sensitive according to privacy laws, regulatory requirements, or business needs.
  • Apply controls as per the classification.
  • Encrypt all data in transit with secure protocols such as TLS with perfect forward secrecy (PFS) ciphers, cipher prioritization by the server, and secure parameters. Enforce encryption using directives like HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS).
References:

  1. https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Authentication
  2. https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/2017/A3_2017-Sensitive_Data_Exposure
  3. https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Transport_Layer_Protection_Cheat_Sheet.html

title: 146 change user selection for proposals
body:
Closes https://github.com/UserOfficeProject/stfc-user-office-project/issues/146 and https://github.com/UserOfficeProject/stfc-user-office-project/issues/152





## Description





Replaced peopleTable for users with proposalPeopleTable so that they cannot see the full user list. Now they can only see users that they have previously collaborated with as well as inviting existing users by email. 





I based the new component on the people table so it has some of the same code and structure.





![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/81559866/125451251-cdbafe73-04af-402c-9b52-4c3c37f91d9d.png)








## Motivation and Context





This solves this GDPR issue: https://github.com/UserOfficeProject/stfc-user-office-project/issues/146





## How Has This Been Tested





For the cypress tests, I have modified them to work on the new table. I then create a dummy proposal then log in as a user officer and edit the proposal from there to render a peopleTable so both tables are tested. 





## Changes





Created new component proposalsPeopleTable.tsx that is rendered when a user is creating a proposal. With this component, users can see users subset of the users that they have previously collaborated with or add an existing user by email. 





The new preivousCobaloraters query finds a user's most recent collaborators (the collaborators from the most recent proposal they worked on) as well as their 10 most collaborated with users.





The email box has some validation on it giving different error messages e.g. User is already on the proposal. It also renders a more detailed message if the email queried does not exist as this within our existing system as there are privacy settings possibly stopping a user from being found. This message may be something we could make site-specific if needed. 








We have also added some logic about who appears in add principal investigator/co-proposer lists based on if they are on the project already.





- If a user is on the proposal already as a principle investigator they will not appear in the lists


- If a user a co-proposer they will not be able to be added a co-proposer. 


- If a user is a co-proposer they can be 'elevated' to the principal investigator, this will remove them as a co-proposer and remove the current principal investigator from the proposal


- If a user removes someone as principal investigator they will become a co-proposer.


- A user cannot remove themselves as a co-proposer





There is now a partipantModel that renders peopleTable or proposalPeopleTable based on if the current userRole, if it, not a user officer, and if a new argument called participant (which is set in proposalParticipant(s) components) is set it renders the proposalPeopleTable else it renders peopleTable.





Created 2 new gql querys: getPreviousColaborators and getBasicUserDeatailsByEmail. 





## Possible Inprovments





Users that have been found by email could have some permeance within the list as currently they are lost when proposalPeopleTable is closed





This is my first time properly coding with react so if there is anything that can be improved around that please let me know. 





I am not sure where else this table might be used or if I have inadvertently placed it somewhere I should not.





## Depends on





Backend PR: https://github.com/UserOfficeProject/user-office-backend/pull/354





Edit: Updated the PI/CoPro logic to complete issue: https://github.com/UserOfficeProject/stfc-user-office-project/issues/152

title: Suggested minor text changes/fixes
body:
1- "Overlays are a broad term for technologies aim to..." should be "Overlays are a broad term for technologies that aim to..."


2- "...the widget is as—at best—redundant functionality..." should be "...the widget is—at best—redundant functionality..."


3- "...product will being the site..." should be "...product will bring the site..."


4- "...this creates GDPR and CCPA risk..." should not assume the reader knows what those acronyms mean and should be "...this creates General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) risk..."


5- "Even more problematic are the deceptive marketing..." should be "Even more problematic is the deceptive marketing..."  because "marketing" is an uncountable noun and should be considered singular.





Cheers!

title: [21.05] Add a GDPR-friendly user purge to pgcleanup
body:
This obfuscates the `email` and `username` columns with `hex(sha1(value + str(int(unix_time))))` (which is how the user manager purges users) when purging deleted users in the `pgcleanup.py` cleanup script. The user manager also obfuscates the user's `UserAddress`es, but `pgcleanup.py` has always just removed those completely (even the non-GDPR version does this).





This tries to avoid changing anything that already exists since the PR is to stable (I'm calling this a bug since the script doesn't do the same thing that Galaxy does), a later dev PR should clean some stuff up:


- The separate handling to zero the `disk_usage` in the original `PurgeDeletedUsers` action seems unnecessary, in the GDPR query I just set it directly to 0 in the `UPDATE`. I assume I did this because I was mindlessly copying the way I did the usage recalculations for active users when purging HDAs?


- Only the first CTE query differs from the non-GDPR version, deduplication would be good (like `PurgesHDA`, but multiple inheritance makes that non-trivial).


- UI user purges are always GDPR-compliant currently, this script allows either, but maybe it should always do GDPR to be consistent with Galaxy. However I can imagine small lab servers not wanting the obfuscation.





## How to test the changes?


(Select all options that apply)


- [ ] I've included appropriate [automated tests](https://docs.galaxyproject.org/en/latest/dev/writing_tests.html).


- [ ] This is a refactoring of components with existing test coverage.


- [x] Instructions for manual testing are as follows:


  1. Create a user


  2. Mark it deleted


  3. Run `pgcleanup.py -d --older-than 0 purge_deleted_users_gdpr`


  4. Observe that the user's `email` and `username` columns are now SHA1 hashes.


  2. We should probably add some tests for this, especially since it deletes stuff...





## License


- [x] I agree to license these contributions under [Galaxy's current license](https://github.com/galaxyproject/galaxy/blob/dev/LICENSE.txt).


- [x] I agree to allow the Galaxy committers to license these and all my past contributions to the core galaxy codebase under the [MIT license](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT). If this condition is an issue, uncheck and just let us know why with an e-mail to galaxy-committers@lists.galaxyproject.org.

title: Next 11.1 site deployed on Vercel shows empty containers on Safari initial load
body:
### What version of Next.js are you using?

11.1.0

### What version of Node.js are you using?

14.16.1

### What browser are you using?

Safari 14

### What operating system are you using?

macOS

### How are you deploying your application?

Vercel

### Describe the Bug

On the first page load of https://chatbooks.com in Safari (both on macOS and on iOS devices (tried on iPad, iPhone, iPad Pro), and ONLY the first page load, the page is rendered with empty containers.





![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2243596/129984997-3b9715c4-76fd-45fb-8130-d312e1c404e8.png)





Looking at the Dev Tools, all of the HTML elements are showing up, including the text/images that should be populating those boxes (the pink bar at the bottom is a GDPR banner, for instance), and all of the elements are interactive. If you hover over a navbar link, the highlight will show and if you click on it, the animation of a panel with a drop shadow is visible, but that panel has no text or images in it.





This ONLY happens on the first load with a clean Browser History. As soon as the page is reloaded once, it loads perfectly every time until the history is cleared (cache, etc.). This also only happens in Safari. Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Opera even all render perfectly. Even IE renders it ugly, but at least the contents are there...

### Expected Behavior

The contents of the page should be displayed on first load.

### To Reproduce

Having never visited https://chatbooks.com, visit in a Safari browser. It's not 100% reproducible, but at least 75% of the time it will load with no contents. Refresh the browser to see the contents of the page load properly.





To eliminate domain issues, you can also visit https://chatbooks.vercel.app and the same thing happens.

title: compute entry id for each received entity notification
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**


At the time being there is no unique identifier of registered timeseries entries. This  may simplify some queries, and help to support some of the ngsi-ld requirements.





From NGSI-LD spec for Properties:


* "instanceId": a URI uniquely identifying a Property instance. System generated. Optional.





For temporal representations, systems should maintain an instanceId for each Property instance. Without


such an instanceId, it is not possible to selectively modify or delete temporal information via the


NGSI-LD API. The consequences of this may be severe in the case of modification or deletion requests


for legal reasons, e.g. GDPR [i.18]. When implementing the NGSI-LD API on storage systems that do


NOT allow modification or deletion, similar problems may be encountered.








**Describe the solution you'd like**


1. When a new entity is received, automatically and id is generated from the backend db.





**Describe alternatives you've considered**





Well doing nothing about it :)





**Additional context**


N/A

title: Data aggregation
body:
is-osm-uptodate only shows points individually at the moment, thus is not very useful over larger areas, because there are too many points to load, render and shown in a meaningful way, without having them overlapping.





# Notes on data fetching and loading





## OSM API





It is possible doing aggregated quality analysis by using OSM API, but only on small areas.





## Overpass API





Overpass API is able to return large areas (like a whole city), but information about the individual nodes should be fetch over multiple OSM API calls, which seems not feasible due to bad performances.





## OSM planet full history





The planet file containing the history cannot be accessed directly as a regular database, because it has no index. It could be interesting to access to it as a Torrent, requesting only the blocks that are needed (there are some proof-of-concept sqlite databases served over torrent), but a spatial index should be generated first and various custom methods to access to the PBF data should be developed, to avoid conversion and import into a regular database, which would use even more space and resources.





## Ohsome





Ohsome [does not support](https://github.com/GIScience/ohsome-api/issues/197) contributors analysis we are doing at the moment, while Overpass API has even [more limited support](https://github.com/frafra/is-osm-uptodate/issues/2) for temporal analysis.





Ohsome provides a fullHistoryBox API which provided mixed results; it seems that it is more convenient not to split the areas in too many subgroups and limit the number of concurrent requests. At the moment, it seems the only viable solution to do such kind of analysis, without having to store and keep synchronized the whole OSM history. It cannot be used to return the list of the unique usernames or user IDs. This is done on purpose: https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/w/images/8/88/GDPR_Position_Paper.pdf.





Ohsome support has been recently merged: https://github.com/frafra/is-osm-uptodate/pull/138. A caching mechanism should follow to further improve performances





# Notes on data rendering/serving





## TMS raster





Data could be rendered as a raster and served as a silly map layer over TMS. This would require the server to apply colors in advance, which can be problematic, as tiles would be rendered in parallel, without knowing the minimum nor the maximum over a given area. That would require some sort of user interaction to set the more appropriate scale while setting some reasonable defaults.





## Leaflet.markercluster





Points could be aggregated in clusters represented by a bigger point. This is the most promising solution at the moment, beign explored by this PR https://github.com/frafra/is-osm-uptodate/pull/145.

title: [new resource]: CLARIN Café on the Rights of Data Subjects in Language Resources
body:
### Title of the resource





CLARIN Café on the Rights of Data Subjects in Language Resources





### Resource type





External Resource





### Authors, editors and contributors





Esther Hoorn, Paweł Kamocki , Aleksei Kelli, Francesca Frontini, Vanessa Hannesschläger





### Topics (keywords)





Training and Education, Open Science, Research Infrastructures, Data Management, DH, Scholarly Practice





### Learning outcomes





After watching this video, you should:





- Understand what rights the GDPR grants to data subjects.





- Understand if these rights are limited when personal data is processed for the purpose of language research.





- Understand how to handle data subjects’ requests related to the exercise of their rights.





- Understand who is responsible for handling data subjects’ requests related to the exercise of their rights.








### Abstract





This training event was a joint collaboration between CLARIN and the TRIPLE project. It was devoted specifically to the rights of data subjects in the GDPR and provided information on the following topics: The rights granted to data subjects by the GDPR; The limitations of these rights when personal data is processed for the purposes of language research; The handling of data subjects’ requests related to the exercise of their rights.

title: Integrate with SIEM systems
body:
## Description

[Security](https://www.cwcwiki.com/wiki/Security) Information and Event Management (SIEM) is a type of software that gathers log data and real-time event data generated from systems throughout an organization?s technology infrastructure and turns it into actionable information. Important uses of SIEM tools include alerting [security](https://www.cwcwiki.com/wiki/Security) staff about immediate [security](https://www.cwcwiki.com/wiki/Security) issues that need to be dealt with, and automated monitoring for compliance with important regulations such as HIPAA, PCI/DSS, and GDPR.

Among the systems that a SIEM solution collates data from are antivirus software, firewalls, host systems, database servers, web filters, network switches, and more. The SIEM tool takes all this information and aggregates it for a broad end-to-end view. The software then analyzes the aggregate data to find patterns and correlations and provide reports on [security](https://www.cwcwiki.com/wiki/Security)-related incidents and events.

### **Best Practices**

- Establish requirements to get a well-defined picture of the requirements for your SIEM deployment, including objectives, prioritized targets from those objectives, and the overall workflow.
- Collect as much diverse data as possible. More information is better when it comes to feeding data into a SIEM system because the essential role of these tools is to take a bunch of log and event data and answer meaningful questions from it. But those questions can't be answered without sufficient data.
- Have a comprehensive incident response plan.


---

so that this turns into a namespace package again

title: Implement `update_index` background worker task
body:
We currently have an `add_crate` background worker task, that gets called when a new crate (or version) is published. This task appends the version metadata to the file in the package index repository which corresponds to the crate.





We currently have another background worker task, `yank`, which gets called when a version is yanked (or unyanked). This tasks changes the `yanked` value in the version metadata in the package index repository.





Our background worker implementation (https://github.com/sgrif/swirl/) mostly runs tasks in order, but, due to built-in retry logic, that is not guaranteed. This means we could end up in a situation where the tasks are run in an order like: unyank, yank, yank, publish, unyank.





Instead of telling the background worker explicitly what action should be performed, it would be better to only tell it to update the package index repository according to the current state in the database.





We should implement a new `update_index(crate_name, version_num)` background worker task, that looks at the state of the index and of the database and then updates the index according to the current state of the database.





In a second step that background worker tasks should ideally then also handle the cases where versions (or even crates) are completely removed from the database due to e.g. GDPR requests.

title: Feature suggestion: Configurable "checked" flag for cookie consent
body:
### Contribution guidelines





- [X] I've read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/squidfunk/mkdocs-material/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and wholeheartedly agree





### I want to suggest an idea and checked that ...





- [X] ... to my best knowledge, my idea wouldn't break something for other users


- [X] ... the documentation does not mention anything about my idea


- [X] ... there are no open or closed issues that are related to my idea





### Description





First of all, I really like the [cookie consent feature](https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/setup/setting-up-site-analytics/?h=consent#cookie-consent) of the insiders project and of course the whole project itself!





As discussed with Waldemar, "Google Analytics" is pre-selected in the cookie settings and hidden when not clicking the "Manage settings" button. 


I'm not a GDPR expert, but regarding a [summary of the "Planet49"-judgement](https://www.oppenhoff.eu/de/news-detail/planet49-urteil-des-bgh-keine-wirksame-einwilligung-zu-cookies-durch-voreingestelltes-opt-in) pre-selected cookies which are not technically required are invalid.


It's stated in the last section under "Was bedeuten diese Entwicklungen für die Praxis?"





Thus, it would be nice to add the "checked" flag as a variable to the mkdocs-config file as part of the cookie consent section, including a minor change of the current config although it is not backward compatible:





```yaml


extra:


  consent:


    cookies:


      analytics:


        checked: true 


        name: Custom name


```





### Use Cases





Changing the config in the described way would also make sure to pre-select individual cookies when further cookies will be added.





### Screenshots / Mockups





_No response_

title: Change youtube embed component to only load src on user request
body:
First mentioned in [this comment](https://github.com/iterative/dvc.org/issues/2980#issuecomment-1002224872)





https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9111807/147594671-99f8f993-07d3-4141-9c7e-fa18af8bd895.mp4





This PR modifies our YouTube embed component such that the `src` is only set after the user clicks a button to watch the video. With this, the embedded site has no way of breaking GDPR compliance through cookies, localStorage, or any other API because the site isn't even loaded until the user wants it to be. I assume we'll probably need to add a message like "By playing this video you accept YouTube's cookies" to be truly GDPR compliant.





We'll have to add our own background images if we want them, but that shouldn't be too difficult given that we can just grab youtube's image and display it on the element- just not as easy to work with should we change the video in the future.

title: Include which user is authenticated in BQ 403 exceptions
body:
A common BQ-related complaint is about the vagueness of Google's 403 exception: `User does not have permission to query table` doesn't contain the relevant info about which user is _actually_ making the call and this can get confusing with the bigquery permissions setup. This PR updates the exception error message to actually include the name of the credentialed user, for example:

RIGHTS.PRINCIPLES: Lawfulness, Fairness, Transparency, right to information
title: Both attributes (ABAC) and capabilities (CBAC) SHOULD be supported
body:
At the moment, a client is able to request with a fine degree a precision a specific set of rights that should be included into an access token. However, a client is unable to request a specific set of attributes that should be included into an access token. 





As a consequence, the support of rights versus the support of attributes is unbalanced.





Implicitly, the core draft mandates a bilateral pre-relationship between every pair of AS / RS. This is not advertised in the draft.





Such bilateral pre-relationship limits the scalability of the architecture. When attributes only are supported, no bilateral pre-relationship between an AS and a RS is necessary.





The core document implicitly only allows an AS to add attributes into an access token at its own discretion, without any specific request for them to be included from the client (and hence the end-user).





This means that the core document does not allow an AS to add specific attributes into an access token upon the request from the client (and hence from the end-user).





This has severe consequences in term of the end-user privacy which are not mentioned in the draft.





First of all, since rights are always included, this means that the AS MUST be aware of the identity of the RS. In addition, the AS cannot be kept ignorant of which actions will be performed by a client and on which resources. **_This allows the AS to act as "Big Brother"._** However, this can be prevented in the case where attributes only are supported.





Secondly, in order to support "good practices" (**_User Notice, User Choice, User Consent and Transparency_**) or legislation like the EU GDPR, the end-user should be informed about the set of attributes that are requested by a RS and should also be able to know the treatment(s) that will be done with such attributes. At the moment, a dialogue between the client and the RS is missing. A specific RS end-point should be defined and dedicated for such dialogue.





If the end-user agrees to provide that set of attributes to the RS, he should be able to indicate to the AS which attributes types (and optionally values) should be included into the access token. At the moment, the client is unable to specify to the AS a set of attributes to be included into the access token. In addition, an end-user is even unable to know which set of attributes are known by the AS.





If this situation is going to last, the privacy consideration section should clearly indicate these limitations.

title: "Privacy policy" is not listed in footer
body:
Although we do have the link "Terms" in our footer (see below), "Terms" is NOT synonymous with "privacy policy". To meet GDPR and CCPA requirements, we should have a conspicuous link to our privacy policy in the footer of our website (so users can find it on every page). 





![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/79384268/150069017-869cc356-a862-44b6-b831-f389b39c9a98.png)





We can create a named anchor on /terms for the "Data privacy and security" section, and the "Privacy policy" link we add to the footer can point directly to the named anchor on the terms page.

title: Current PHAR distribution errors on PHP 8.1
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the title above. -->


Current PHAR distribution of gdpr-dump (Version 2.3.0) errors on PHP 8.1. This **DOES NOT** happen when installing gdpr-dump from git (and do a fresh `composer install`). I guess it's related to the version of `symfony/console` shipped in the PHAR.





Edit: Okay, it's not the version of `symfony/console`. The error occurs due to the way gdpr-dump PHAR build works. The `Compiler` class uses `php_strip_whitespace` to strip all the comments from source code, which eliminates the `#[\ReturnTypeWillChange]` attribute.





### Preconditions


<!--- Provide detailed information about your environment. -->





<!-- GdprDump Version : Which version of GdprDump are you using? -->


GdprDump Version: 2.3.0





<!-- PHP Version : Which version of PHP are you using? -->


PHP Version: 8.1.2





<!-- Database Version : Which database application are you using (MySQL, MariaDB, Percona...), and which version? -->


Database Version: MariaDB 10.4





### Steps to reproduce


<!--- Provide a set of unambiguous steps to reproduce this bug. You can also include pieces of code if you think it's relevant. -->


1. Just execute `php gdpr-dump.phar --help`





### Expected result


Help should be printed without errors





### Actual result


Fatal Error:


```


Fatal error: During inheritance of IteratorAggregate: Uncaught ErrorException: Return type of Symfony\Component\Console\Helper\HelperSet::getIterator() should either be compatible with IteratorAggregate::getIterator(): Traversable, or the #[\ReturnTypeWillChange] attribute should be used to temporarily suppress the notice in phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Helper/HelperSet.php:2


Stack trace:


#0 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Helper/HelperSet.php(2): Smile\GdprDump\AppKernel->Smile\GdprDump\{closure}(8192, 'Return type of ...', 'phar:///usr/loc...', 2)


#1 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/composer/ClassLoader.php(2): include('phar:///usr/loc...')


#2 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/composer/ClassLoader.php(2): Composer\Autoload\includeFile('phar:///usr/loc...')


#3 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Application.php(2): Composer\Autoload\ClassLoader->loadClass('Symfony\\Compone...')


#4 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Application.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Application->getDefaultHelperSet()


#5 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Command/Command.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Application->getHelperSet()


#6 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Application.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Command\Command->setApplication(Object(Smile\GdprDump\Console\Application))


#7 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Application.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Application->add(Object(Symfony\Component\Console\Command\HelpCommand))


#8 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Application.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Application->init()


#9 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/src/AppKernel.php(2): Symfony\Component\Console\Application->add(Object(Smile\GdprDump\Console\Command\DumpCommand))


#10 phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/bin/gdpr-dump(2): Smile\GdprDump\AppKernel->run()

#12 {main} in phar:///usr/local/bin/gdpr-dump/vendor/symfony/console/Helper/HelperSet.php on line 2

title: Importing institutional certifications and permissions [Long term goal?]
body:
# Importing institutional certifications and permissions





## Motivation and context


As the brainlife platform moves towards engaging clinical researchers and/or groups using non-open (or otherwise protected) datasets, it may be worthwhile to begin exploring how to transfer / query / verify institutional permissions for accessing particular datasets. 





Currently, as I recall it, access to a dataset / project is managed by the admin of that project.  Beyond that protocol though, there aren't really any guardrails in place to constrain their activities as admin.  In this way they are at their liberty to add other users to the project / dataset as they see fit.  Particularly for open datasets this is ideal and allows for nimble development and analysis in a project.  However, for projects potentially involving clinical or other protected data, this setup may be too permissive.  As such, it may be worthwhile to look in to how to import certifications from third parties, as a means of controlling or compartmentalizing access to components of a dataset / project.





## Outline of approach





Currently there are a number of regulatory protocols and certifications  for research and data practices, including (among **many**):





- The [Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI)](https://about.citiprogram.org/) program


- The [Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA)](https://www.cdc.gov/phlp/publications/topic/hipaa.html)


- [Various institutional regulations (e.g. Institutional Review Boards (IRB) or other institutional protocols; [UT Austin](https://security.utexas.edu/policies/sensitive_research)]





In may cases the required trainings for these certifications are served or managed by online platforms like [Canvas](https://www.instructure.com/canvas) or [CITI](https://about.citiprogram.org/), and are digitally transferred and recorded by consumer institutions.  Given that there appear to be systems in place to **digitally and automatedly** manage and administrate these certifications it seems that it may be quite technically feasible to incorporate these in the brainlife ecosystem.





### Foreseen challenges





#### Lack of obvious APIs


A quick check of CITI reveals [this page](https://webservices.citiprogram.org/), which provides some documentation of some forthcoming tools and methods which could facilitate this process.  Beyond this there doesn't appear to be much in the way of per-packaged approaches to this.





#### Lack of central protocol


While it is true that many institutions appear to be using the same internal methods for serving and documenting training compliance (i.e. Canvas), it's not clear that there is any standardization of these internal records that would permit the coordination, transfer, or updating of such information with 3rd parties (i.e. brainlife). 





#### Lack of standard certification 


Although federal and state regulations require that research institutions ensure and maintain compliance with ethical / security / procedural regulations, the specific means by which this is implemented aren't explicitly dictated or standardized.  As such institutions (and their respective IRBs) are at their discretion insofar as how they actually do this.  This means that different organizations, even in the same state or perhaps even in the same institutional system, may have different standards and methods for establishing and assessing certification.





##### Certification standardization sidenote


There's reason to believe that this "wild west" approach may be drawing to a close.  Europe's [General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)](https://gdpr-info.eu/) is indicative to a more centralized and top-down approach to data security and compliance.  The existence of a standard like this would seem to permit the subsequent development of standardized certification procedures / protocols.  In the US there is [an ongoing push for data protection standards of this sort](https://www.whitehouse.gov/ostp/news-updates/2021/11/10/join-the-effort-to-create-a-bill-of-rights-for-an-automated-society/), (also described [here](https://iapp.org/news/a/federal-data-privacy-regulation-is-on-the-way-thats-a-good-thing/)), which could similarly lay the groundwork for a standardized certification criterion.  Legislation of this sort will likely take several more years, but it may be worthwhile to be an early-adopter / path-forger in this domain.





## Tentative proposal 


Given that the scope (in that the infrastructure likely needed is non-trivial) and impact (in that such capabilities would be useful to other groups like [datalad](https://www.datalad.org/), [OpenNEURO](https://openneuro.org/), etc), it may be more appropriate to pursue this as part of a consortium or larger grant proposal (like this expired(?) [NIH Request for information](https://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/notice-files/NOT-OD-21-157.html)). In such a case it would probably be advisable to narrow the scope of this to the domain of neuromingaging data even though the methods/protocols developed would likely be easily adapted for other contexts. 





## Future extension


A similar process may also be appropriate for documenting / certifying the security and access characteristics of [compute resources](https://brainlife.io/resources).  Indeed, this may actually be a more tractable possibility, as the (currently( limited number of these systems would likely allow us to manually curate and codify these properties.

title: Content negotiation / Missing triples
body:
**Content negotiation**


Attempting to dereference [https://w3id.org/dpv#](https://w3id.org/dpv#) (using Postman, or CURL) and explicitly setting the HTTP Accept: header to be text/turtle returns HTML, and not Turtle.


But dereferencing [http://www.w3.org/ns/dpv#](http://www.w3.org/ns/dpv#) does indeed return Turtle for DPV.





**Triples describing DPV as an ontology are missing**


The returned turtle file [here](https://github.com/w3c/dpv/blob/master/dpv/dpv.ttl) only has triples describing DPV-GDPR and not DPV:





```


<https://w3id.org/dpv/dpv-gdpr> a owl:Ontology ;


    dct:abstract "The GDPR extension to Data Privacy Vocabulary provides terms (classes and properties) related to EU General Data Protection Regulation."@en ;


    dct:contributor ...


```

title: Cookie Banner Guidelines
body:
[OneTrust Cookie banners](https://app.onetrust.com/auth/login) are commonly used on Trimble websites for GDPR and California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) compliance.





The default banners styling is not Modus compliant (colors/fonts/sizes etc). We should  provide guidelines on styles to use.

title: UseCookiePolicy breaks all manager POSTs
body:
Hello,


I needed to add GDPR accept cookie, [standard official implementation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/gdpr?view=aspnetcore-6.0).





Using:





- NET 6.0


- Piranha 10.0.2 (every package)


- Firefox 98.0.1


- Edge 99.0.1150.46


- Brave 1.36.119 Chromium: 99.0.4844.83





When I go to the website, I can click accept GDPR cookie, it shows up in browser's cookie list with accepted status. Working as intended.





When I go to the manager, I can log in, read, open everything. But every POST inside the manager returns `400 bad request`. Removing the GDPR cookie config from Startup fixes the issue.





```C#


options.MinimumSameSitePolicy = Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.SameSiteMode.Unspecified;


Edge: works


Brave: bad request


Firefox: bad request


```


all other options, including `options.HttpOnly =  HttpOnlyPolicy.None` and `options.Secure = CookieSecurePolicy.Always` or any mix or other modes of the three don't work at all.





Log from Edge:


```


       POST https://localhost:5001/manager/api/page/save 400


saveInternal @ piranha.pageedit.min.js:1


save @ piranha.pageedit.min.js:1


click @ VM1019:3


invokeWithErrorHandling @ piranha-deps-dev.js:19892


invoker @ piranha-deps-dev.js:20217


original._wrapper @ piranha-deps-dev.js:25570


piranha.min.js:1 


        


       Uncaught TypeError: Cannot set properties of undefined (setting 'visible')


    at piranha.min.js:1:7211


(anonymous) @ piranha.min.js:1


setTimeout (async)


push @ piranha.min.js:1


(anonymous) @ piranha.pageedit.min.js:1


Promise.then (async)


saveInternal @ piranha.pageedit.min.js:1


save @ piranha.pageedit.min.js:1


click @ VM1019:3


invokeWithErrorHandling @ piranha-deps-dev.js:19892


invoker @ piranha-deps-dev.js:20217


original._wrapper @ piranha-deps-dev.js:25570


```





Noticed the issue https://github.com/PiranhaCMS/piranha.core/issues/1829, but I'm using the latest Piranha.





## Steps to reproduce:





1. dotnet new piranha.razor


2. add to `ConfigureServices`


```C#


            services.Configure<CookiePolicyOptions>(options =>


            {


                // Sets the display of the Cookie Consent banner (/Pages/Shared/_CookieConsentPartial.cshtml).


                // This lambda determines whether user consent for non-essential cookies is needed for a given request.


                options.CheckConsentNeeded = context => true;


                options.MinimumSameSitePolicy = Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.SameSiteMode.Strict;


            });


```


add `UseCookiePolicy()` to `Configure`


```C#


            // Configure Tiny MCE


            EditorConfig.FromFile("editorconfig.json");





            app.UseCookiePolicy();





            // Middleware setup


            app.UsePiranha(options => {


                options.UseManager();


                options.UseTinyMCE();


                options.UseIdentity();


            });


```


3. Go to manager, try saving/publishing a page





it doesn't matter if the GDPR cookie is accepted, since the manager should be marked essential Piranha 10.0.1 and newer?


I feel like I'm missing something obvious... Do I need to add it via `options.Services.AddCookiePolicy` and `options.Builder.UseCookiePolicy().Build()` or something now?





Interestingly, an older .NET Core 3.1 and Piranha 8.3.1 project with UseCookiePolicy() works without issue.

title: Enhance soft-delete for GDPR compliance
body:
<!--


Thank you for suggesting an idea to make HumHub better.





Please fill in as much of the template below as you can.


-->








### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.





When a user soft-deletes themselves their name is not deleted from the database. This is not GDPR compliant





### Describe the solution you'd like





Content by a given user remains, but their name is removed from it. All personal data (email address etc) is deleted from the database.





### Describe alternatives you've considered





Some further discussion here: https://community.humhub.com/s/general-discussion/post/post/view?id=14316

title: Add MASKING_STRICT Config and allow Delete Escalation [#324][#325]
body:
❗ Needed for #354 





# Purpose





Add MASKING_STRICT param. By default this is True, but if False, we can use a GDPR delete request, or a DELETE request if no UPDATE request is configured.





# Changes





-  When `SaaSConnector.mask_data` is called, we instantiate the `query_config` for the given Node and pull the masking request from that node's config, escalating to GDPR Delete or Delete if necessary.  Previously, we would just pull the `update` method by default in `SaaSQueryConfig.generate_update_stmt`


  - Error thrown if primary_key is defined on collection, but no masking request is configured. 


- Allow a `data_protection_request` to be configured on a SaaSConfig - this can potentially be called multiple times, limiting this is out of scope.  To constrain to just one collection, only define a primary_key on one collection for GDPR delete.





# Checklist





- [x] Applicable documentation updated (guides, quickstart, postman collections, tutorial, fidesdemo, [database diagram](https://github.com/ethyca/fidesops/blob/main/docs/fidesops/docs/development/update_erd_diagram.md))


- [x] Good unit test/integration test coverage


- [ ] This PR contains a DB migration. If checked, the reviewer should confirm with the author that the [down_revision correctly references the previous migration](https://ethyca.github.io/fidesops/development/contributing_details/#alembic-migrations) before merging


- [x] The `Run Unsafe PR Checks` label has been applied, and checks have passed, if this PR touches any external services





# Ticket





Fixes #324, #325

title: Verified the use of "Personal Data", expand list of module considerations
body:
- Verified the use of "Personal Data (PD)" instead of "Personally Identifiable Information (PII)". Personal Data is a broader term that encompasses Personally Identifiable Information. Organizations that are subject to GDPR are obligated to protect a user's personal data.


- Expand the modules specific checklist to include processing and logging of Personal Data.


- Organize list of types of personal data to emphasize data that is identifiable by itself.

title: GDPR Inflections
body:
## What type of PR is this? (check all applicable)





- [x] Refactor


- [ ] Feature


- [ ] Bug Fix


- [ ] Optimization


- [ ] Documentation Update





## Description


It came up in [this PR](https://github.com/forem/forem/pull/17538#discussion_r864598236) that we're titlizing the sidebar navigation items, and hence "GDPR delete requests".titleize will result in "Gdpr Delete Requests". 





Hence, we want to create an inflection for the GDPR Delete Requests and amend the class names in the files as per this rule. 





## Related Tickets & Documents





<!--


For pull requests that relate or close an issue, please include them


below.  We like to follow [Github's guidance on linking issues to pull requests](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue).





For example having the text: "closes #1234" would connect the current pull


request to issue 1234.  And when we merge the pull request, Github will


automatically close the issue.


-->





- Related Issue #


- Closes #





## QA Instructions, Screenshots, Recordings





1. Start up the app, and navigate to the [GDPR Delete Requests page](http://localhost:3000/admin/users/gdpr_delete_requests). Click around and make sure that everything still works. 





2. In addition, I changed a migration file so run `rake:db:drop; rake db:create; rake db:migrate; rake db:seed` and make sure everything works. 








### UI accessibility concerns?





None





## Added/updated tests?





- [ ] Yes


- [x] No, and this is why: _please replace this line with details on why tests


      have not been included_


- [ ] I need help with writing tests





## [Forem core team only] How will this change be communicated?





_Will this PR introduce a change that impacts Forem members or creators, the


development process, or any of our internal teams? If so, please note how you


will share this change with the people who need to know about it._





- [ ] I've updated the [Developer Docs](https://developers.forem.com) or


      [Storybook](https://storybook.forem.com/) (for Crayons components)


- [ ] This PR changes the Forem platform and our documentation needs to be


      updated. I have filled out the


      [Changes Requested](https://github.com/forem/admin-docs/issues/new?assignees=&labels=&template=changes_requested.md)


      issue template so Community Success can help update the Admin Docs


      appropriately.


- [ ] I've updated the README or added inline documentation


- [ ] I've added an entry to


      [`CHANGELOG.md`](https://github.com/forem/forem/tree/main/CHANGELOG.md)


- [ ] I will share this change in a [Changelog](https://forem.dev/t/changelog)


      or in a [forem.dev](http://forem.dev) post


- [x] I will share this change internally with the appropriate teams


- [ ] I'm not sure how best to communicate this change and need help


- [ ] This change does not need to be communicated, and this is why not: _please


      replace this line with details on why this change doesn't need to be


      shared_





## [optional] Are there any post deployment tasks we need to perform?





## [optional] What gif best describes this PR or how it makes you feel?





![alt_text](https://media.giphy.com/media/coijcQneuNxPTLWPoQ/giphy.gif)

title: May 2022 Release Plan
body:
# Prerequisites





-   Python 3.7 and higher


-   run `python3 -m pip install --user -r news/requirements.txt`





# Release candidate (Friday of VS Code endgame week, XXX XX)





-   [x] Review [Component Governance](https://dev.azure.com/monacotools/Monaco/_componentGovernance/191876) (Click on "microsoft/vscode-jupyter" on that page) and resolve all High/Severe issues.





    -   [x] Manually add any repository dependencies (if you can't add manually, refer [here](https://docs.opensource.microsoft.com/tools/cg/features/cgmanifest/)). Only add a cgmanifest.json if the components are not NPM or are not dev only.


-   [x] Create new release branch with format `release/release-YYYY.MM.100`


    -   [x] Create a pull request against `release/release-YYYY.MM` for changes


    -   [x] Run `npm install` to verify `package-lock.json` did not get updated.


    -   [x] Update [`CHANGELOG.md`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md)


        -   [x] Run [`news`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-jupyter/tree/main/news) (typically `python news --final --update CHANGELOG.md | code-insiders -`)


        -   [x] Copy over the "Thanks" section from the previous release into the "Thanks" section for the new release


        -   [x] Make sure the "Thanks" section is up-to-date (e.g. compare to versions in [`requirements.txt`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/main/requirements.txt))


        -   [x] Touch up news entries (e.g. add missing periods)


        -   [x] Check the Markdown rendering to make sure everything looks good


    -   [x] Update [`ThirdPartyNotices-Repository.txt`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-jupyter/blob/main/ThirdPartyNotices-Repository.txt) as appropriate. This file is manually edited so you can check with the teams if anything needs to be added here.


    -   [x] Merge pull request into `release/release-YYYY.MM`


-   [x] Update the [`release` branch](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/branches)


    -   [x] If there are `release` branches that are two versions old (e.g. release-2020.[current month - 2]) you can delete them at this time (you would have to un-protect the release branches temporarily to delete them).


-   [x] Update `main` after creating the release branch. (Warning: this should happen right after creating the release branch. If this is deferred till later, the `main` and `release` branches can diverge significantly, which may cause merge conflicts.)


    -   [x] Merge the changes from release (Changelog, delete news, ThirdPartyNotices) into `main` branch


    -   [x] Bump the version number to the next monthly ("YYYY.M.100") release in the `main` branch


        - If latest is `2022.2.100`, them bump it to `2022.3.100`,


        - This ensures the new new pre-release targets the next version.


        -   [x] `package.json`


        -   [x] `package-lock.json`


        -   [x] Confirm the 3rd part of the version ends with `100`.


    -   [x] Update the VS Code engine version in package.json (for release version) to target the upcoming stable release. This will allow us to release before VS Code and be ready in the marketplace. [Example](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/pull/9494/files)


    -   [x] Create a pull request against `main`


    -   [x] Merge pull request into `main`


-   [x] GDPR bookkeeping (@greazer) (🤖; Notes in OneNote under Python VS Code -> Dev Process -> GDPR)


-   [x] Open appropriate [documentation issues](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Apython)


    -   new features


    -   settings changes


    -   etc. (ask the team)


-   [x] Release notes from VS Code have something about Jupyter


    -   Example doc update [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/pull/5256)


-   [x] Schedule a sanity test. Aim for close after freeze so there is still time to fix release bugs before release. Ask teams before bash for specific areas that need testing.


-   [x] Is the validation pipeline clear? If not, drive to make sure that it is clear for release. Sanity test can be used to help with this.


-   [x] Ask CTI to test the release candidate





# Testing (Monday of VS Code release week, XXX XX)





-  [x] Obtain VS Code [prebuild](https://builds.code.visualstudio.com/builds/stable) for sanity testing


-  [x] Sanity test release candidate VSIX against VS Code prebuild


   -   Make sure that the sanity test hits both macOS and Windows builds


-  [x] Candidate bug fixes found from sanity test should be checked into `main` and cherry-picked to `release` branch





# Release (Tuesday or day before VS Code publishes, whichever is later)





## Preparation





-   [x] Make sure the [appropriate pull requests](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/pulls) for the release notes(https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-docs/blob/vnext/release-notes/v<vscode version>.md, make note of the branch and file name).


    - [x] Include all new new features under a section named `Jupyter` with screenshots or animated gifs.


    - [x] Fixes, code health should remain in the Jupyter change log.


-   [x] Make sure [Component Governance](https://dev.azure.com/monacotools/Monaco/_componentGovernance/191876) is happy


-   [x] Make sure there is nothing targeting this release that still needs to be validated


        (`is:issue sort:updated-desc milestone:"<milestone>" label:verification-needed -label:verified`)





## Release





-   [x] Publish the release


    -   [x] Verify the PR Pipeline on Github actions is green against the release branch.


    -   [x] Manually run the [Stable pipeline](https://dev.azure.com/monacotools/Monaco/_build?definitionId=284) against the `release/release-xxxx.xx` branch


    -   [x] Approve the `Publish` stage


    -   [x] For manual (if needed as automatic should be tried first)


    -   [x] Go to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/releases and add a new release


        -   [x] Tag is version number


        -   [x] Branch is release branch


        -   [x] Copy contents of release branch changelog into the release (just copy the markdown)


        -   [x] Publish


-   [x] Determine if a hotfix is needed


    -   [x] Ensure the version in package.json is updated as follows:


        * If released version is `YYYY.MM.100`, then hot fix will be `YYYY.MM.110`


        * If released version is `YYYY.MM.110`, then hot fix will be `YYYY.MM.120`





# Day of VS Code publishing (Wednesday, XXX XX)


-   [x] Go through [`info needed` issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-jupyter/issues?q=is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-asc+label%3Ainfo-needed) and close any that have no activity for over a month (🤖)


-   [x] GDPR bookkeeping (🤖) ((@greazer does regular classification every Monday evening))


-   [x] If any steps were unclear or changed in this release plan please update the `release_plan.md` file to make it clear for the next release





# Day of VS Code releasing the next insider version (Wednesday, XXX XX)


-   [x] Bump the engines.vscode version on the `main` branch to point to the next insider version. For example, from `1.58.0-insider` to `1.59.0-insider`





## Prep for the _next_ release





-   [x] Create a new [release plan](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/microsoft/vscode-jupyter/main/.github/release_plan.md) (🤖)


    * Title `<Month> <year> Release Plan`


    * Add the labels `endgame-plan` to this issue


    * Pin this issue


-   [x] [(Un-)pin](https://help.github.com/en/articles/pinning-an-issue-to-your-repository) [release plan issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-jupyter/labels/release-plan) (🤖)

CONCERNS.coder.1: Law information page/policy, Links to law information
CONCERNS.coder.2: Law information page/policy, Links to law information
CONCERN.FINAL2: Law information page/policy, Links to law information

title: Add blindsend to File Management and Sharing
body:
Hi, I'd like to suggest a tool we made at [blindnet](https://blindnet.io) to be added to the list. 





### Blindsend


<!--- Replace what's between "<" and ">" --->


* [Blindsend](https://github.com/blindnet-io/blindsend) - Open source tool for private, end-to-end encrypted file exchange.


* **License**: MIT Licence


* **Why do you think this helps users privacy?**: Many users still use e-mail or non-encrypted file-transfer services to exchange sensitive (and often confidential) files. Even professionals (lawyers, doctors) request personal and sensitive data from their clients to be sent by e-mail. Blindsend encrypts files in the browser, before they reach the internet. It is easy to use, even for non-technical users. The parties exchanging files can remain anonimous.


* **Under what section should this service be listed?**: File Management and Sharing


* **Additional comments / info**: In the EU, thanks to the [Article 32 of GDPR](https://gdpr-info.eu/art-32-gdpr/) it is illegal for professionals (such as lawyers, doctors, etc.) to request sensitive personal information to be sent to them in non-secure ways (such as e-mail). In France, failure to comply with this obligation can get professionals fined up to 300.000 EUR and 5 years of jail time, see [Art. 226-17 of French Criminal law](https://www.cnil.fr/fr/les-sanctions-penales).





So it is very important for professionals in EU to move away from e-mail and wetransfer, and adopt services listed here. Blindsend is our contribution to making a step in the right direction.


<!--- If you want to list more than one service on this same issue, use the same format as above for each service. --->

title: GDPR consent string is always empty
body:
Hello team,





I've been trying to send the GDPR consent string to the server. Here's what I've tried:


```


TargetingParams.setSubjectToGDPR(true)


TargetingParams.setGDPRConsentString("COvFyGBOvFyGBAbAAAENAPCAAOAAAAAAAAAAAEEUACCKAAA.IFoEUQQgAIQwgIwQABAEAAAAOIAACAIAAAAQAIAgEAACEAAAAAgAQBAAAAAAAGBAAgAAAAAAAFAAECAAAgAAQARAEQAAAAAJAAIAAgAAAYQEAAAQmAgBC3ZAYzUw");


```





and


```


PreferenceManager.getDefaultSharedPreferences(applicationContext).edit().apply {


            putBoolean("IABConsent_CMPPresent",true)


            putString("IABConsent_SubjectToGDPR", "1")


            putString("IABConsent_ConsentString", "COwK6gaOwK6gaFmAAAENAPCAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA.IFoEUQQgAIQwgIwQABAEAAAAOIAACAIAAAAQAIAgEAACEAAAAAgAQBAAAAAAAGBAAgAAAAAAAFAAECAAAgAAQARAEQAAAAAJAAIAAgAAAYQEAAAQmAgBC3ZAYzUw" )


            apply()


        }


```


Both won't work. Here is part of the openrtb2.BidRequest I get on the server:


```


"regs":{"ext":{"gdpr":0}},


```





GDPR is always set to 0, and there's no trace of consent string. What did I do wrong?

title: Requests to api.zcxv.icu
body:
At the moment every redirect is send to api.zcxv.icu (with https://api.zcxv.icu/b2s.php?q=set&url=...&redir=...). The service seems to be used to save the redirects online. Using the context menu, redirects can also be entered manually. The API can also be queried for sites and returns known redirects (https://api.zcxv.icu/b2s.php?q=get&url=...). Some thoughts about this:





* I think it's dubious that users are not made aware, that all matched pages they are visiting are logged. what other data (IP address, the like) is logged? At least where I live (EU juridistriction) it is illegal to log such data without notice (according to GDPR), and must at least be mentioned in the readme


* is it possible and b2s.php secure enough to make the application open source?


* the recorded data is not to be trusted: currently it is possible to create a redirect from page A to a phishing/malware/whatever page B (using https://api.zcxv.icu/b2s.php?q=set&url=https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2Fa&redir=https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2Fb), page A is returned without checks from the API (https://api.zcxv.icu/b2s.php?q=get&url=https%3A%2F%2Fexample.com%2Fa), there should be at least a check on the php-side, if the entered redirect pages are valid stack exchange / github / ... pages

title: Updated the readme
body:
Read me can be found below:








# Code4Me


Code4Me provides automatic intelligent code completion based on large pre-trained language models. Code4Me predicts statement (line) completion and is available for both PyCharm (also other JetBrains IDEs) and Visual Studio Code. The code suggestions from Code4Me can be recognised by the logo in the suggestion menu. Code4Me automatically triggers (on specific trigger characters) or the user can prompt it manually by pressing the keybind. The keybind differs per IDE:





- Jetbrains: **ALT + SHIFT + K**


- VSC: **CTRL + SPACE**





Code4Me does not hinder native auto completion or other extensions.





## Installation


The plugin is available on both marketplaces. You can download them by either clicking the link in your browser or looking up 'Code4Me' in the integrated marketplace of your IDE.





### JetBrains


The Code4Me plugin can be found in the [JetBrains Marketplace](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/19200-code4me).





### VSC


The Code4Me plugin can be found in the [Visual Studio Code Marketplace](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Code4Me.code4me-plugin).





## Data Collection


The plugin works with a remote API in order to suggest autocompletions. After triggering the autocompletion (automatically or manually), the client's request is sent to the server. Running the ML-based model, the server returns a prediction in response to the client. The remote API requires a segment of the current document (close left context at the trigger point). This limited segment is sent to the backend server only for prediction and will not be stored on our server. 


For the purpose of evaluating the models' predictions, we only store the suggestion made by the ML-based models at each trigger point and compare it against the accepted prediction by users (collected after 30 seconds). 





The plugin does not collect personal data nor the segment sent. The plugin does collect the following data:





* Suggest autocompletion.


* Verification of the autocompletion.


  * The plugin tracks the line the code was inserted and sends that line to the server after 30 seconds.


* Inference time of completion.





Furthermore, Code4Me is in full compliance with the GDPR and all data is anonymous. The data collected will remain on the servers of TU Delft until the end of the study. By using Code4Me you give permission for the data collection.





## Source Code


The source code for the IDE plugins and the API webserver can be found at our GitHub [repository](https://github.com/code4me-me/code4me).

title: Support payment method update b49ce
body:
As a user, I would like to be able to update my existing payment methods.
Currently, the system support a single payment method - a credit card, and once a user adds a new card, the previous card details are discarded.
In the new flow, we'd like to be able to register multiple payment methods, such as bank account and paypal. Additionally, we'd like to be able to store multiple payment methods of the same type, like two credit cards for a customer.
The payment methods form should include -
1. Payment method type
2. Payment method details
In case the payment method is a credit card, we'd need to store:
1. Credit card issuer
2. Credit card number
3. CVV
4. Expritation date
5. Owner first name
6. Owner last name
In case the payment method is a bank account, we'd need to store:
1. Bank ID
2. Bank account number
3. Branch ID
4. Owner first name
5, Owner last name
Since the details are sensitive and personal, the user must verify login prior to the update.
Since the details are GDPR protected, the data must be encrypted, both at transit and at rest.

title: Sign > share > donate flow doesn't require GDPR opt-in selection for European users
body:
###  Context:
We have an alternative after-action flow used by some petition and signup pages. Instead of redirecting to a separate thanks page, it keeps users on the same page after signing, and asks them to share and then donate, eg.

https://act.350.org/sign/stop-jackdaw-gas-field-uk/
https://act.350.org/sign/custom_page_field_demo_petition/

Whether we use this flow or the standard thanks page is toggled by the custom page field "After-action – Next Step"
https://act.350.org/admin/core/allowedpagefield/after_5Faction_5Fnext_5Fstep/change/

When users select a European country on the form, they are automatically shown GDPR opt-ins and asked to opt-in to receive emails if they don't already have a privacy record on file. 

Selecting a Y or N answer to these opt-in radio boxes should be required, so people have to choose an answer to whether they would like to receive followup emails from us. This is the case for petition and signup pages which uses the standard thanks page:

https://act.350.org/sign/custom_page_field_demo_petition_standard_thanks/
https://act.350.org/sign/banks-stop-funding-destruction-argentina/

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22962348/172732616-b4c939eb-b357-4f98-871c-de80b6a7ea90.png)

The "Please select an option above" message is set in the language strings:
https://act.350.org/admin/core/language/1/change/
and it actually looks like the duplication is because we have 2 versions of this, `error_privacy:missing` and `error_privacy:required`  #349 

### Bug:

However in Chrome Version 102.0.5005.61 and Firefox and Safari on mac, this EN version of the page is validating the required Name and email fields ok, but not the Europe opt-ins. You can skip the opt-ins and scroll right on down:
https://act.350.org/sign/stop-jackdaw-gas-field-uk/

![Image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22962348/172732662-6403055d-3fa0-40d0-b2a0-7082a55a7092.png)


### Exceptions:
Opt-ins won't be shown for European users that are recognised and already have a privacy record, so when they are hidden they of course shouldn't be required
AK's handling of GDPR is documented here: https://act.350.org/docs/manual/guide/privacy.html?highlight=privacy.html

I also noticed another bug where when content blockers are allowed in Safari, the form won't submit at all, we just see a "loading" beach ball -  #346


### This will be done when:

- [x] On a petition or signup page using the Sign>share>donate flow eg.
https://act.350.org/sign/stop-jackdaw-gas-field-uk/
https://act.350.org/sign/custom_page_field_demo_petition/
users who see the GDPR opt-ins (ie. are in Europe and don't have a privacy record) are not be able to submit the form without selecting an answer to the opt-in questions, and see a "Please select an option above." message.

title: [Feature]: Please support named Ngrok tunnels
body:
### What type of project(s) will this request affect?

app

### What type of change do you want to see?

New feature

### Overview

We often use named Ngrok tunnels, please allow this as a configuration option or read it from the ngrok settings.

### Motivation

Randomized ngrok urls break webhooks, specifically mandatory gdpr webhooks which are defined in the partner dashboard webhooks section.





Randomized ngrok urls break origins used on CDN platforms, where they may be important even in development.

Easyprivacy requests:


** If a site implements any tracking or monitoring, UA/IP/Geo checks, browser detection, analytics, telemetry, linking to third-partys, pixels, referrers, fingerprinting, event/perf logging etc. Regardless how helpful or needed the script(s) are, it will be blocked in Easyprivacy. Privacy comes first and the block on these scripts will remain in place.

title: [Interim Spectacle Application form] Implement Step 1 "Dossier de candidature" form
body: Implement step 1 form for Interim Spectacle "Dossier de candidature"(Application form) form : 1. Use **/interim-spectacle-dossier-candidature** for the link type base url 2. The form consists of the following elements: **Title of the form:** "Dossier de candidature" / "Application form" **Page 1:** - **Date field:** "Date de candidature"/"Application date" - **Text field:** "Comment avez-vous connu Intérim Spectacle ?" / "How did you find out about Interim Spectacle?" **Sub title:** "État civil" / "Personal information" - **Text field:** "Nom" / "Last name" **(required)** + **Text field:** "Prénom" / "First name" **(required)** on same line - **Text field:** "Nom de jeune fille" / "Maiden name" - **Single choice radio buttons":** - **label:** "Sexe"/"Sex" - **choice 1:** "Masculin"/"Male" - **choice 2:** "Féminin"/"Female" - **Text field:** "Numéro de sécurité sociale"/"Social Security number" - **Date field:** "Date de naissance"/"Birth date" + **Text field:** "Lieu de naissance : ville, département et pays"/"Place of birth: city, department and country " on same line **Page 2:** - **Text field:** "Adresse (fiscale) : n° rue, code postal et ville" / "Address (fiscal): n° street, postal code and city" - **Multiple files upload field:** "En cas d’hébergement chez les parents, amis ou autres... fournir une attestation signée avec copie de la carte d’identité du ou des concerné(s)"/"In case of accommodation at parents, friends or others... provide a signed certificate with a copy of the identity card of the concerned person(s)" **with file name:** "attestation-hébergement" / "accommodation-certificate" - **Text field:** "Situation familiale" / "Family situation" + **Text field:** "Nombre de personnes à charge :"/"Number of dependents" on same line - **Text field:** "Quels sont vos loisirs ?" / "What are your hobbies?" **Page 3:** **Sub title:** "Coordonnées personnelles"/"Contact information" - **Text field:** "Téléphone Domicile" / "Home phone" + **Text field:** "Mobile" / "Mobile phone"**(required)** - **Text field:** "E-mail"/"Email" - **Text field:** "Personne à contacter en cas d'accident : Nom et téléphone"/"Contact person in case of accident: Name and phone number" **Page 4:** **Sub title:** "Qualifications"/"Qualification" - **Text field:** "Métier recherché"/"Profession wanted" **(required)** + **Text field:** "Expérience"/"Experience" on the same line - **Text field:** "Autre métier pouvant être exercé (1)"/"Other profession that can be exercised (1)" + **Text field:** "Expérience"/"Experience" on the same line - **Text field:** "Autre métier pouvant être exercé (2)"/"Other profession that can be exercised (2)" + **Text field:** "Expérience"/"Experience" on the same line - **Text field:** "Autre métier pouvant être exercé (3)"/"Other profession that can be exercised (3)" + **Text field:** "Expérience"/"Experience" on the same line - **Text field:** "Type d’emploi recherché"/"Type of job sought" - **Toggle buttons** : (such as these ones from covid form: ) - Toggle button 1: "Uniquement intérim"/"Only interim" - Toggle button 2: "CDI"/"CDI" - Toggle button 3: "CDD"/"CDD" - Toggle button 4: "Emploi vacances scolaires"/"Employment during school holidays" - **Text field:** "Formation souhaitée"/"Desired training" **Page 5:** **Sub title:** "Compléments d’informations"/"Additional information" - **Date field:** "Date de disponibilité "/"Availability date" **(required)** - **Date field:**"Date dernière visite médicale"/ "Date of last medical visit" + **Multiple files upload field:** "Justificatif dernière visite médicale"/"Proof of last medical visit" on the same line **with file name:** "justificatif-visite-medicale" / "medical-visit-proof" - **Toggle button:** "Êtes-vous libre de tout engagement professionnel ?"/"Are you free from any professional commitment?" - **Toggle button:** "Avez-vous un moyen de déplacement (véhicule personnel) ?"/"Do you have a means of transportation (personal vehicle)?" **(required)** - **Toggle button:** "Êtes-vous inscrit à Pôle emploi ?"/"Are you registered at Pôle emploi?" + **IF YES** **Toggle button:** "Depuis plus d'un an ?"/"For more than one year?" on the same line - **Toggle button:**"Percevez-vous le RSA ?"/ "Do you receive the RSA?" + **IF YES** **Multiple files upload field:** "Justificatif RSA"/"Proof of RSA" on the same line **with file name:** "justificatif-RSA" / "RSA-proof" **Page 6:** **Sub title:** "Compléments d’informations"/"Additional information" -**Toggle button:**"Avez-vous été victime d’un accident de travail ?"/ "Have you been the victim of an accident at work?" + **IF YES** **Text field:** "Quelles blessures/maladies avez-vous subi ?"/"What injuries/illnesses have you suffered?" on same line - **Toggle button:**"Vos blessures sont-elles existantes ?"/"Do your wounds still exist?" - **Toggle button:**"Percevez-vous une I.P.P. ?"/"Do you receive a I.P.P. ?" - **Toggle button:**"Avez-vous un statut de personne handicapée ?"/"Do you have a disabled person status?" + **IF YES** **Text field:** "Lequel ?"/"If yes, which one?" on same line - **Toggle button:**"Avez-vous des contre-indications médicales liées à une tâche professionnelle ?"/"Do you have any medical contraindications related to a professional task?" + **IF YES** **Text field:** "Lesquelles ?"/"Which one?" on same line - **Toggle button:**"Craignez-vous le vertige ?"/"Are you afraid of vertigo?" - **Toggle button:**"Utilisez-vous des matériels à risque ?"/"Do you use risky equipment?" + **IF YES** **Text field:** "Lesquels ?"/"Which one?" on same line - **Toggle button:**"Possédez-vous des équipements de sécurité ?"/"Do you have security equipment?" + **IF YES** **Text field:** "Lesquels ?"/"Which one?" on same line 3. **Add legal consent text** at the end of the form : FR: ``` Toutes vos réponses sont confidentielles et sont enregistrées de manière chiffrée par PrivateForm. Elles seront accessibles uniquement par le responsable de traitement, [@client] [@email]. Le responsable du traitement est habilité à collecter ces informations, qui seront utilisées dans le cadre de votre relation contractuelle ou précontractuelle avec le responsable du traitement ainsi que pour les besoins des services fournis. Votre consentement explicite est demandé par ce formulaire. Elles seront stockées en Europe pendant toute la durée de votre relation contractuelle avec le responsable du traitement et ensuite pour un délai maximal de [@numberOfMonths] avant d’être automatiquement supprimées. En accord avec le RGPD, une fois votre formulaire envoyé vous pourrez exercer vos droits d’accès, de modification et de suppression sur vos données. Pour plus d’informations vous pouvez contacter : [@client] [@email] [@contact] ``` EN: ``` All your answers are confidential and are encrypted by PrivateForm. They will be accessible only by the data controller, [@client] [@email]. The data controller is authorised to collect this information, which will be used in the context of your contractual or pre-contractual relationship with the data controller as well as for the needs of the services provided. Your explicit consent is requested by this form. They will be stored in Europe for the duration of your contractual relationship with the data controller and then for a maximum period of [@ numberOfMonths] before being automatically deleted. In accordance with the GDPR, once your form has been sent, you can exercise your rights of access, modification and deletion of your data. For more information you can contact: [@client] [@email] [@contact] ``` 4. **Add one consent option** at the end of the form : FR: ``` J’accepte que les données que j’ai renseigné soit collectées, consultées et utilisées pour l’exercice de l’activité de [@client] ``` EN: ``` I agree that the data I have entered will be collected, consulted and used for the exercise of the activity of [@client] ``` 5. Use the following **PDF templates** : [FR. Interim Spectacle 2 Application form PDF template](https://docs.google.com/document/d/11QUdhnhvv-kPxiD-A92FpLR2tMpvZvibEGWoS5pGrSc/edit#) / [EN. Interim Spectacle 2 Application form PDF template](https://docs.google.com/document/d/11QUdhnhvv-kPxiD-A92FpLR2tMpvZvibEGWoS5pGrSc/edit#)
